The major indexes are capping a fine week with moderate gains in late-afternoon trading Friday. The surprising bump up in the number of fresh breakouts serve as corroborating evidence that institutional investors are warming again to stocks.Stocks gave up some gains after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said an interest rate hike would be "appropriate" in the coming months, but soon firmed again. The Nasdaq composite led the upside, up 0.4%, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrials 0.1%. Smaller companies outperformed, with the S&P 600 up 0.6% and the mid-cap S&P 400 up 0.4%. Volume was tracking lower on both exchanges ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend.Veeva Systems (VEEV) rushed 10% higher, further moving past a 28.05 handle within a four-month cup base. That base is nestled within a much longer and deeper base. The software firm focuses on the health care industry and is rising on a 25% jump in fiscal first-quarter profit to 15 cents a share, smashing Wall Street's 11-cent view. Revenue rose 33% to $120 million, accelerating from gains of 28% and 31% in the prior two quarters.The 25% profit jump is especially impressive when considering that in the year ago April-ended quarter, earnings blasted 140% higher to 12 cents a share.Veeva, an October 2013 IPO, earns an excellent Composite Rating of 95 on a scale of 1 to 99. It's part of IBD's Computer Software-Medical industry subgroup.What other companies beside Veeva hold outstanding IBD Ratings? Check for free at IBD Stock Checkup.Weibo (WB) is rising past a 24.89 buy point in a tight consolidation that could serve as an entry point for aggressive investors. The China-based Twitter-like service had broken out of an excellent cup with handle at 19.20 in early April. On the retailing side, Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Dollar General (DG) have moved sharply past proper buy points at 83.82 and 87.52, respectively. Such action among leading individual stocks reflects growing confidence that the Federal Reserve plans to further normalize the cost of money with the possibility of raising interest rates either in June or July. The Fed in December last year hiked the fed funds rate for the first time since 2006. But rates remain drastically low; the 10-year Treasury yield remains below 2%. On Friday, Fed chief Janet Yellen made comments during a Q&A session at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., indicating that she too is ready to remove some "policy accommodation."Low interest rates actually help stocks in the sense that the so-called "earnings yield" for S&P 500 firms is higher than long-term bond yields. With the consensus estimate for full-year 2016 earnings at roughly $119 and the S&P 500 trading near 2093, the index's earnings yield stands at 5.7%.S&P Global Market Intelligence estimates that earnings in 2016 will rise a little more than 2%.On Tuesday, IBD's Market Pulse showed a change in the current outlook to "Uptrend resumes" from "Uptrend under pressure" as the major indexes continued to rally and distribution days expired. But the overall distribution count remains elevated.

Bears and bulls alike showed patience late Thursday afternoon as the stock indexes stayed close to the break-even level. The market is likely waiting for the second take on first quarter GDP, which will be released Friday before the opening bell.The Nasdaq inched up 0.3% Thursday, the S&P 500 rose 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally lower. The Dow Jones utility average led the upside with a 0.9% pop. Volume was running lower on both major exchanges.GDP has been revised upward in each of the previous three quarters' second takes. In the first Q1 estimate, GDP came in at a weak 0.5%. The Street's consensus view expects the percentage to be adjusted upward to a still-sluggish 0.9%. The range of estimates ran from 0.5% to 1.1%.On Thursday, blue chips were mostly down. Of the 30 stocks in the Dow, only one attracted higher volume. Apple (AAPL) cranked up volume more than 40% above the usual pace, gaining 1.1% to 100.69. The stock is headed toward its fifth daily gain in a row and was testing its 100 price level. Apple has wiped out most of the losses tied to its April earnings report. The stock chart, though, still looks ugly.A report from Morgan Stanley says Apple is spending heavily on auto technologies' research and development. Apple’s R&D spending rose 30% in Q1 to $2.51 billion. This kind of investment could bring Apple back into the growth camp. Some market analysts say that Apple is now more of a conservative stock than a growth stock.How many failing red marks does Apple get in IBD Stock Checkup?Economic news was generally bullish Thursday. Durable goods orders in April bulldozed past the Street's estimate. April's increase was 3.4% vs. views for 0.3%. The March percentage was revised upward from 0.8% to 1.9%. Meanwhile, first-time jobless claims came in lower than expected.Pending home sales for April boomed 5.1% vs. views for 0.8%. The home sales number reached the highest level in 10 years. The reaction, however, among housing stocks was subdued. For example, D.R. Horton (DHI) was flat as the market headed into its final hour of trade.The one negative note came from the Kansas City Fed's manufacturing gauge. The needle pointed to minus 5 in May vs. minus 4 in April. Manufacturing, which accounts for 12% of GDP, has been a sore point in the U.S. economy.Breakouts Thursday included Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR). Dollar General rose 5% intraday while Dollar Tree shot up 13.5%, both on earnings reports.

Deep-discount variety store chains Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Dollar General (DG) crushed first-quarter earnings estimates amid strong expansion, driving shares up early Thursday.Dollar Tree said Q1 EPS jumped 25% to 89 cents, compared to views for 71 cents. Revenue of $5.09 billion was more than double the same quarter in 2015 on a 2.3% increase in same-store sales and its $8.5 billion purchase of Family Dollar in July, which boosted sales.Dollar Tree shares shot up 12.8% to 88.37, rising above an 83.82 buy point of a flat base to a new all-time high.Revenue was below analysts' consensus of $5.1 billion. Still, Chief Executive Bob Sasser said in a written statement he was generally pleased with the company's performance in "what continues to be a challenging economic environment."The company projects second-quarter earnings of 66-72 cents a share and sees $5.03 billion-$5.12 billion revenue. Consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for 75 cents earnings per share and $5.1 billion revenue.Meanwhile, rival Dollar General's first-quarter adjusted earnings climbed 23% to $1.03 a share, and revenue grew 7% to $5.27 billion. Wall Street expected 95 cents earnings per share and $5.28 billion revenue.It was the second quarter in row of better-than-expected earnings after the company missed in the prior three quarters last year amid strong competition from Amazon.com (AMZN) and big-box discount chains such as Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Target (TGT).For the quarter ended April 29, Dollar General's same-store sales at outlets open more than a year grew 2.2% vs. the same quarter a year earlier, and operating profit rose 16 basis points to 30.6%. The company said it plans to open 900 new stores this year.Dollar General has been forming a flat base with an 87.52 buy point, pushing it close to its all-time high at 87.42 set on April 1. Dollar General shares finished trading up 4.6% to 88.01 in the stock market today.

Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) disappointing fiscal Q4 guidance late Thursday led to stock downgrades and lowered price targets, while Splunk (SPLK) saw higher price targets, and Barclays upgraded NuVasive (NUVA) to overweight.Deutsche Bank and Needham downgraded the network security software maker to hold. Piper Jaffray lowered its price target to 167 from 180, and RBC Capital lowered its target to 185 from 195.Palo Alto Networks forecast current-quarter adjusted profit and revenue below consensus estimates and reported a bigger fiscal Q3 loss, though revenue surged 48%.Shares closed down 12.4% Friday.Citigroup raised its price target on Splunk, a data analytics software provider that has moved into security, to 62 from 53. BMO Capital Markets hiked its target to 58 from 55, and Pacific Crest Securities hiked its PT to 70 from 67.Splunk late Thursday reported revenue and billings, a sales growth metric, that topped views, though current-quarter guidance was light. Splunk’s analytics service is available on cloud computing platforms such as Amazon (AMZN) Web Services.Splunk shares finished 2.6% higher.Barclays upgraded San Diego-based NuVasive to overweight with a PT of 63, citing the acquisition of its Brazilian distributor, stability outside the U.S. and the launch of Attrax.Nuvasive shares climbed 3.1%.Barclays initiated coverage on two other spine treatment companies, rating Globus Medical (GMED) equal weight and LDR Holding (LDRH) overweight.RBC Capital raised its PTs on deep-discount variety store chains Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Dollar General (DG). Both reported higher-than-expected Q1 earnings.Dollar Tree’s “Q1 sales were solid, but significant margin upside was the real story this quarter,” said RBC Capital, which raised its PT to 101 from 94. RBC Capital increased its PT on Dollar General to 98 from 91.Dollar Tree shares closed up 0.65%, adding to 12.8% surge Thursday, and Dollar General rose 2.1%, following Thursday's 4.6% gain.In other analyst moves, Citigroup downgraded Deckers Outdoor (DECK), Needham initiated PayPal (PYPL) at hold, and Wedbush downgraded Workday (WDAY) ahead of its earnings report next week.

Stocks rose Friday, ending at session highs, as investors shrugged off disappointing economic data and comments by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggesting higher interest rates were on the way.The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 added 0.4%, and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.3%. Volume fell about 11% on the NYSE and 7% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary data. The market is closed Monday for the Memorial Day holiday.Yellen said an interest rate hike is possible “in the coming months” amid improved economic growth. Traders put the probability of a rate hike at the Fed's June 15 meeting at 30% and the chance of an increase at the July meeting at 62%, according to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool.Also Friday, Q1 GDP was revised upward to 0.8% -- less than expected -- and the University of Michigan’s consumer sentiment gauge for May also fell short of Wall Street’s consensus estimate.Retail stocks once again outperformed in the stock market today.Discount retailer Big Lots (BIG) jumped 14% to a new high in heavy volume after announcing that profit for the fiscal first quarter ended in April jumped 34% from a year earlier to 82 cents a share, well above Wall Street estimates. Revenue rose 3% to $1.3 billion, also well above views.The stock rocketed back above a 46.23 buy point in massive volume, just nine days after it triggered a sell signal by sinking 8% below the entry.Big Lots is the latest discount retailer to spike to new highs following a strong earnings reports. Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) continued to rise Friday following earnings-inspired breakouts Thursday.FEI (FEIC) led the S&P 500, jumping 14%, after Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) said it would buy the maker of electron microscopes for $4.2 billion.Zoes Kitchen (ZOES), Medtronic (MDT), YY (YY) and Workday (WDAY) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings on Tuesday.

An 11% gap-up gain by Big Lots (BIG) early Friday sealed a strong week for discount and variety chains. Dollar Tree (DLTR) spiked 13% in its own gap-up move Thursday, following its quarterly report. Also on Thursday, Dollar General (DG) rumbled nearly 5% higher in high-volume trade. Five Below (FIVE) and Ollie’s Bargain Outlet (OLLI) caught the updraft, ending the week up…

The major indexes held onto gains in the early afternoon Friday, as discount retailers continued to defy weakness in the sector.Semiconductor and software stocks were among the day's best performers, helping the Nasdaq to a 0.5% gain. The S&P 500 was up 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%.Volume was tracking lower across the board -- no surprise on the Friday before a three-day weekend. Winners led losers by 12-to-7 on the NYSE, and by nearly 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.Discount and specialty retail stocks led the market, one day after Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) surged on strong earnings reports. Dollar General added 2% Friday and remained in buy range from an 81.52 buy point. Dollar Tree inched higher and is extended from an 83.82 buy point of a flat base.Five Below (FIVE), another part of the discount retailing group, added nearly 4%. Five Below will announce earnings Thursday after the close.Weibo (WB) cleared a short consolidation, surging 8% in heavy volume to a new high. The Chinese Twitter (TWTR)-like social platform may be rising in sympathy with Alibaba (BABA), which is rebounding in fine form after news of an SEC investigation into its accounting sparked a 7% plunge Wednesday in the Chinese e-commerce company. Alibaba owns about a third of Weibo.Alphabet (GOOGL) rose more than 1%, rising above its 50-day moving average for the first time since April 21. Late Thursday, a federal jury found that Alphabet's Google didn't need authorization to use Oracle's Java programming tools as it built the Android smartphone operating system. Oracle (ORCL) claimed Google had stolen its intellectual property.Universal Display (OLED), whose display technology is being added to a number of electronic devices, and telecom infrastructure company Dycom Industries (DY) cooled off a bit from sharp price gains earlier in the week.

Stocks ended little changed Thursday ahead of revised first-quarter GDP figures, due Friday before the opening bell.The Nasdaq edged up 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1%, and the S&P 500 ended fractionally lower. Volume fell on both major exchanges in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.In after-hours trading, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) jumped 7% after the big-box cosmetics retailer reported that fiscal Q1 profit rose 39% to $1.45 a share on a 24% increase in sales to $1.07 billion. Both figures easily topped Wall Street estimates.Ulta, which rose 1% to a new high during the regular session, has climbed out of buy range following a March breakout past a 188.58 buy point.Veeva Systems (VEEV), a developer of cloud-based software for life-sciences firms, was up 9% in post-session trading after a strong fiscal Q1 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session near a 52-week high and slightly extended from a 28.05 handle entry.Discount retailers led the gains in the stock market today.Dollar General (DG) jumped 5%, clearing an 87.52 buy point of a flat base in heavy volume after reporting that profit for the latest quarter rose 23% to $1.08 a share, beating Wall Street estimates. Sales climbed 7% to $5.3 billion.Dollar Tree (DLTR) soared more than 13% in massive turnover, clearing an 83.82 flat-base buy point, also on strong earnings.In economic news, durable goods orders rose more than expected in April, and the figure for March was revised higher. Meanwhile, first-time claims for jobless benefits fell more than expected. Friday's revised GDP report is expected to be adjusted upward to a still-sluggish 0.9% increase.Homebuilders rose after pending home sales for April jumped 5.1%, well above the expected 0.8% gain, to the highest level in 10 years. Hovnanian Enterprises (HOV) and LGI Homes (LGIH) each rose 2%.On the downside, Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) plunged 16% in huge volume after the struggling apparel retailer posted a bigger-than-expected loss of 59 cents a share in the latest quarter. Revenue fell 3% to $685.5 million.

Stock futures stuck to narrow gains ahead of Thursday's open. Rising oil prices, healthy durable goods and jobless claims data and earnings news all figured into early action.Futures for the Dow industrials, Nasdaq 100 and the S&P 500 all held gains to less than 0.2%.Durable goods orders leapt 3.5% in April, clobbering consensus forecasts for a 0.3% increase. The Commerce Department also revised March's estimate upward to a 1.9% gain vs. initial estimates of an 0.8% increase. Minus transportation, orders rose a mere 0.4% — in line with expectations.Jobless claims improved slightly, declining to 268,000 in the week ended May 21. That was down from the prior week's 278,000 claims and well below projections for a 275,000 total.April pending home sales are expected from the National Association of Realtors at 10 a.m. ET. The Kansas City Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing index is set for an 11 a.m. release, and Federal Reserve Board Governor Jerome Powell has a speech scheduled at 12:15 p.m.Oil rose a bit less than 1%, with West Texas Intermediate bobbing above and below the $50 mark. Gold added half a percent to $1,230 an ounce. The dollar eased. Bonds were largely flat.Dow issues leaned generally higher just before the open. Wal-Mart (WMT) topped the group with a 0.5% gain.Dollar Tree (DLTR) led the S&P 500, jumping 9% after reporting cost-cutting initiatives that boosted first-quarter earnings above analyst views. The stock has been unable to muster enough lift to clear a prior, 80.14 buy point, but technically ended Wednesday's session 7% below an 83.72 flat base buy point.Dollar General (DG) muscled up 3% following its Q1 report. Earnings rose 23% to top targets by 8 cents.  Revenue climbed 7%, just a shade short of expectations. Dollar General ended Wednesday's session 4% below an 87.52 buy point in a flat base.Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger brand owner PVH (PVH) rocketed 7% higher after first-quarter earnings cleared estimates, and management raised its second-quarter earnings and revenue guidance, and full-year earnings guidance, to above consensus views. PVH is in the eighth week of a potential base pattern.Among IBD 50 stocks, Gigamon (GIMO) added 2% before the open. The network performance gear maker is fighting to gain some lift above a 29.62 buy point, after tripping a sell rule by erasing gains above the buy mark early in May.WebMD (WBMD) dropped 5% in premarket action. The online health information and professional networking site for medical trades announced a $300 million offering of convertible debt. Shares ended Wednesday extended 15% above a 58.35 buy point, and 4% past a 64.10 buy point from a three weeks tight pattern.Lion's Gate Entertainment (LGF) traded a fraction lower after reversing an early, 13% spike. It reported a better-than-expected fourth quarter, boosted by a record performance for its television segment.Steel maker stocks were busy as indications that the European Commission may be expanding an investigation against China’s steel export practices. Arcelor-Mittal (MT) swept up nearly 10%. U.S. SteelX spiked 6%. The steel makers industry group is up 77% from a January low, and ranks No 2 among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD.Global markets also kept to tight gains. Markets in China and Japan ended their sessions on Thursday only narrowly higher. In Europe, the leading benchmarks crept up less than 0.5% in midday trade.

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day Specialty retail darling Ulta Beauty (ULTA), cybersecurity specialist Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and discount-store peers Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Dollar General (DG) are on tap to report earnings. Retail results have been pretty grim so far -- but will the specialty beauty retailer…

Sellers battered retailers on Wednesday on a range of company and earnings news, but discount chains have held up better.In late trading, retail and apparel industry groups had 16 of the day’s 20 worst losses among the 197 groups tracked by IBD.That’s a tough day.The stock market has been hard in general on the retail sector, with retail groups holding four of the 10 worst industry rankings. One exception has been discount and variety stores, essentially the dollar-store chains. Those were in the top five rankings on Wednesday and have held top-20 rankings for nearly eight straight weeks.Dollar stores for the past several years have offered a combination of defensive and offensive plays. Like Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), the stores tend to attract more customers when economic times turn tough, as consumers hold down spending. At the same time, they have provided a growth story as the once highly fragmented industry consolidates into a smaller numbers of larger players.But the group wasn’t immune to Wednesday’s selling pressure.Get a closer look at Macy's fine points using IBD's Stock Checkup feature.Five Below (FIVE), Big Lots (BIG), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Ollie’s Bargain Outlets (OLLI) and Dollar General (DG)  slid.But none of that really caused any chart damage within the group, with one exception. Five Below pared its losses after diving almost 8% in opening trade. It had already tripped a sell signal last week, after falling more than 8% below a 42.36 buy point. Wednesday's action showed the stock losing its grip on its 50-day moving average. It also sent shares more than 8% below a prior buy point of 41.57, triggering a sell rule for investors who bought at that level.Ollie’s has been the group’s barn-burner, ripping ahead 27% from a March 18 breakout to a peak on April 28. Anywhere above a 20% increase from the buy point would have been a good place for investors to book profits. Those who held on rode a pullback over the past three weeks. Shares are now testing support at the 10-week moving average and about 10% above the stock's buy point.If the stock rises off its 10-week line in strong trade, it would present an add-on buying opportunity. If it cuts that line in heavy trade, it could mark a sell signal, depending on how severely the stock breaks support.Ollie’s sells name-brand goods -- from clothing to sporting goods to flooring and food -- at steep discounts. The bargain chain operates some 200 stores across the East.Dollar General took a light bounce off support at its 10-week moving average. It is working on the sixth week of a flat base with an 87.52 buy point. It is in a base-on-base pattern, with its low sitting around the high of a prior base. Dollar General broke out of that pattern after reporting its Q4 results on March 10. The company plans to report Q1 results on May 19.All the companies in the group operate on a January year-end calendar.Dollar Tree had outflanked Dollar General last year, spending $8.5 billion to win over Family Dollar and bump Dollar General out of a bid for market dominance. The deal left the dollar-store market with two peers of essentially equal size: Dollar Tree-Family Dollar with nearly 14,000 stores and Dollar General with just under 13,000.Dollar General's revenue for fiscal 2015 was $20.4 billion. Dollar Tree-Family Dollar booked revenue of $15.5 billion. In terms of earnings, analysts' consensus is for a 15% rise in Dollar General’s EPS this year in what would make a tenth straight advance.Dollar Tree’s outlook: a 55% jump in EPS and a 35% surge in revenue as the company fully digests Family Dollar. Next year estimates slow to a 23% earnings gain and a 6% sales rise.Despite the sharp upturn in financials, the jury is still out among investors with regard to the Dollar Tree-Family Dollar combo. Shares have traded sideways since January after recovering from an October low, but they remain about 6% below their March 2015 high.Big Lots is the group’s struggling turnaround story. Quarterly earnings and revenue have wobbled up and down. The stock continues to trade at about 14% below a November 2014 high.The stock is basing, but fundamentals continue to look weak. Earnings are forecast to grow 11% this year on a 1% revenue gain, rising to a 14% gain next year with revenue growth holding steady.

Investors this week learned to stop worrying and love the rate hike. Even as Fed officials and fresh economic data bolstered the case for a summer interest rate increase, stocks rallied. Apple (AAPL) and banks continued to climb, while energy stocks took heart from $50 oil. Top-rated Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and deep-discount stores shrugged off retail earnings woes. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) kept spinning. Alibaba (BABA) disclosed an SEC accounting probe, while Alphabet (GOOGL) and Bank of America (BAC) won key court battles.Odds for a Federal Reserve rate increase at the June or July meetings continued to climb, but stocks rallied. The Nasdaq rose 3.4%, the S&P 500 2.3% and the Dow industrials 2.1%, with all three regaining their 50-day lines as the market direction returned to a confirmed uptrend. Apple advanced 5.4% after climbing 5.2% last week. Financial and energy stocks also rallied, with the latter rising along with oil prices. U.S. crude oil futures briefly topped $50 a barrel Thursday, a seven-month high, as U.S. inventories and production fell. Crude rose 3.3% for the week to $49.33.Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen, who has been among the more dovish policymakers publicly in recent months, said Friday that raising rates cautiously would be "appropriate" in the coming months as the economy continues to improve. Earlier in the week, San Francisco Fed President John Williams said he sees two or three rate hikes this year, with three or four more next year. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard reiterated that the U.S. job market is tight and may start to push inflation higher -- cause for another rate hike. Fed Gov. Jerome Powell said the benchmark rate could go up soon, but weak productivity growth could curb further increases.While odds of a rate hike at the June policy meeting are about 33%, the chances for at least one quarter-point hike by the July meeting are above 60%.Economic data largely backed calls for a rate hike. New-home sales spiked 16.6% to an eight-year high, while pending-home sales shot up to their best level in 10 years. Durable goods orders rose 3.4% on soaring aircraft demand, but the report also showed core capital goods bookings slid to a five-year low.In the coming week, May data on manufacturing (ISM index), U.S. auto sales and employment may lock in expectations for or against a Fed rate hike.Automaker-tech pairings continued. Toyota (TM) said it will invest an undisclosed amount in Uber after last year disclosing plans to invest $1 billion in R&D on self-driving cars. Toyota will offer auto leases to Uber drivers. BMW i Ventures said it will invest in Scoop Technologies, creator of the Scoop carpooling mobile app. Volkswagen (VLKAY) will invest $300 million in Gett, an Uber rival in Europe and New York City. The trio join Apple, which in early May said it would invest $1 billion in top China ride-hailing service Didi Chuxing as it reportedly works in secret on an Apple Car project. (Didi itself is backed by Alibaba and Tencent (TCEHY), while Uber partners in China with Baidu (BIDU)). Also, General Motors (GM) in January said it would invest $500 million in Lyft, an Uber rival.The specialty beauty retailer continues to be an outperformer among a field of retail disappointments. Ulta Beauty notched a 39% EPS gain -- the biggest in three years -- on 24% revenue growth to $1.07 billion, way above views. Ulta also amped up its full-year outlook. Q2 guidance was mixed. More retailers are scheduled to report this week. Shares rose 11.8% for the week, mostly on Friday's post-earnings jump.IBD's Take: How beautiful is Ulta's stock based on IBD criteria, and does it stand out vs. rivals? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupDollar-or-less variety store chains Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) crushed first-quarter earnings estimates Thursday amid strong expansion. Dollar General reported a 23% EPS gain and plans to open 900 new stores this year. Dollar Tree reported a 25% EPS advance. One troubling sign was that both fell short of Wall Street revenue targets. Still, Dollar Tree CEO Bob Sasser said he was generally pleased with the company’s performance in “what continues to be a challenging economic environment.”Dollar General stock leapt 10.1% this week, and Dollar Tree gained 15.7%, both breaking out to new highs.Alibaba disclosed an ongoing SEC investigation into potential violations regarding the e-commerce giant’s transaction and consolidation practices, as well as its operating data from Singles Day, the Chinese company’s most lucrative shopping day of the year.Shares plunged 6.8% Wednesday, Alibaba’s worst one-day percentage decline in more than a year. But Alibaba ended 2.8% higher this week.Evercore, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank analysts all said they remained positive on the stock.Hewlett Packard Enterprise said it would spin off its Enterprise Services business and merge it with Computer Services Corp. (CSC), a move the company said would create a $26 billion global IT behemoth. HPE, itself a spin-off of Hewlett-Packard, also kept its full-year EPS guidance above views.HPE stock rose 15.1% for the week. Computer Sciences spiked nearly 41% to a six-month high.Bank of America, Citigroup (C), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and other big banks are back on the hook for a potentially crippling sum of cash after a U.S. appeals court overturned a 2013 lower-court ruling against antitrust lawsuits that alleged the banks rigged Libor and hurt investors. The lower court found the plaintiffs didn’t show sufficient harm, but the appeals court felt the opposite. Now the lower court will deliberate further on the matter and decide whether the plaintiffs are justified to sue at all.That same appeals court overturned a $1.27 billion suit against Bank of America that alleged the bank’s Countrywide Financial misled mortgage giants Fannie Mae (FNMA) and Freddie Mac (FMCC) on loan sales in the run-up to the financial crisis. The court said Countrywide’s actions were likelier to fall under "breach of contract" rather than outright fraud. The court also dismissed a civil suit against Rebecca Mairone, who was once an executive at Countrywide.A jury ruled that Alphabet's Google didn't need approval from Oracle (ORCL) to use the latter's programming tools -- APIs -- to build Android, the world's leading mobile operating system. Oracle had sought $9 billion in damages and possible additional royalties, saying Google violated its copyrights. But the jury said the Alphabet unit exercised fair use. Oracle said it will appeal.Alphabet stock rose 3.6% for the week, closing back above its 50-day moving average.Monsanto (MON) agreed that a deal with Bayer (BAYRY) made financial sense, but the agriculture giant rejected the $122 per share, or $62 billion offer, saying it was worth more money. But it also said it was open to more talks. Bayer said it looks to further talks with Monsanto and said it could address potential financing and regulatory issues. Monsanto stock rose 7.85% to 109.49. Bayer fell 5% to a 3-year low.Gannett (GCI)  threatened to withdraw its $15 per share offer for Tribune Publishing (TPUB) after the the owner of the L.A. Times and Chicago Tribune issued 4.7 million new shares and sold them to Nant Capital. The investment firm Towle, which controls 3.85% of Tribune shares, blasted the move and said it supports an acquisition by Gannett.Tribune Publishing stock dived 20.9% after spiking 24% in the prior week. Gannett stock fell 3.2%.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) guided to $386 million to $390 million in fiscal Q3 sales and 48-50 cents earnings per share ex items, missing the midpoints of the consensus model of $389.3 million and 50 cents. The No. 2 cybersecurity firm's fiscal Q2 sales grew 48% year over year to $345.8 million, topping Wall Street for $339.5 million. Q2 EPS shot up 83%, though that merely met analyst forecasts.Palo Alto shares dived 8.4% this week after crumbling 12.4% on Friday.Tiffany (TIF) reported Q1 EPS fell 14.8% to 69 cents but beat views by a penny. Sales fell 7.4% to $891.3 million, under views for $915.1 million. European and Asia-Pacific same-store sales were down 15%, while Americas unit comps were down 10% on lower tourist spending. But the jeweler raised its quarterly dividend 12.5% to 45 cents per share.Tiffany shares rallied to close up on Wednesday, but they lost 3.3% for the week.Signet Jewelers (SIG) said Q1 EPS jumped 20.4% to $1.95, beating views by a penny. Revenue climbed 3.3% to $1.58 billion, but fell short of views for $1.61 billion. Same-store sales were up 2.4%. For Q2, Signet, which owns the Zales, Kay and Jared mall-based jewelry chains, sees EPS of $1.49 to $1.54 vs. analyst estimates for $1.52. It also projects comps growth under analysts' forecasts.Signet stock fell 7.1%.

Quarterly reports from Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's (LOW) could provide some relief to the…

Consumer stocks have come into focus on the Big Cap 20 list of hot growth stocks as earnings have been reported or soon will be. One member of the group that will report Wednesday after the close is O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY). A well-received first-quarter report could trigger a breakout above a 277.93 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The company…

The rally that began in February has disappointed growth stock investors. Their best names have done little. But one group that stands out is the discount retailers. The industry group is ranked No. 6, rising from No. 43 three months ago. It's up 17.4% year to date as of Tuesday's IBD. That's in contrast to a 2.2% decline for the…

Under Armour (UA) was downgraded Wednesday, while Halliburton (HAL) and CVS Health (CVS) got price target hikes and Apple (AAPL) supplier Cavium (CAVM) was upgraded.Under Armour was downgraded to hold at Brean Capital, in large part due to  the late Tuesday's news that two top executives will leave Under Armour, including its chief merchandising officer.The sportswear company said Tuesday that it had extended its contract with the Washington Nationals' Bryce Harper. Financial terms weren't disclosed. ESPN reported that Harper got a 10-year extension, the largest endorsement deal in history for a Major League Baseball player.Under Armour shares closed down 7.5% in the stock market today, tumbling below its 50-day line.IBD's Take: How fit is Under Armour stock? And how does it compare to key rivals? Find out at IBD Stock CheckupCowen lifted its price target on Halliburton to 40 from 33, days after the oilfield services provider terminated its merger deal with Baker Hughes (BHI). Halliburton fell 1.4%.Mizuho raised its price target on CVS Health to 117 from 104 after the drugstore chain topped earnings and revenue forecasts. CVS Health was flat.Cavium was upgraded to buy by Benchmark, a day after Brean initiated coverage on the Apple supplier with a buy rating.Cavium shares dipped 1.3%. Apple shares lost 1%, a day after ending an 8-day losing streak.Dollar General (DG) was upgraded to buy with a 100 price target at Bank of America. Dollar General shares edged 1.3% higher.RBC Capital started department stores Nordstrom (JWN) and Macy’s (M) with sector perform ratings and 51 and 42 price targets respectively. RBC initiated coverage on Kohl’s (KSS) with an underperform rating and 42 price target. The industry is "walking a tightrope," RBC said. Shares of all three department store chains fell more than 2%.Hospital operator Tenet Healthcare (THC) was downgraded by Mizuho to neutral. Heath insurance provider Molina (MOH) was downgraded to sell with a 45 price target at Goldman Sachs. Tenet fell 1.5% and Molina 3.6%.

After watching its main rival fatten up on a big acquisition last year, deep discount retailer Dollar General (DG) has something smaller in mind for 2016 -- namely, the size of some of its stores.The company has announced plans to expand its test of its smaller-format stores this year even as other retailers, Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) in particular, have abandoned the concept.Dollar General currently is trying out around 30 of the smaller-format stores, which are less than 6,000 square feet vs. 7,400 square feet at the typical location. Earlier this month the company said it will open about 80 smaller-format stores this year as part of an overall plan to open 900 new stores.The smaller stores help Dollar General "capture growth opportunities" in more densely populated metropolitan areas, Chief Executive Todd Vasos said on a March 10 conference call with analysts."Sales productivity and returns based on the early results are very encouraging," Vasos said. "By eliminating less productive product segments and adding or expanding product departments to meet the needs of our urban customers, we believe this smaller-format store will allow us to have higher capture rate per-site selection."He also reckons that the concept will work well in sparsely populated rural areas."With this smaller format, we have even greater confidence in our real estate strategy for metro sites and smaller, lower household rural sites," Vasos said.Dollar General no doubt hopes to have a better go of it with the smaller format than Wal-Mart. The retail giant’s Express concept also aimed to capture more business in densely populated urban areas, but ultimately fell flat with consumers.There are some obvious differences between Wal-Mart and Dollar General, however -- the biggest being the gap in size between small and large formats.Dollar General’s smaller stores only have about 1,400 fewer square feet than typical stores. In contrast, Wal-Mart’s Express stores, at about 15,000 square feet, were around 170,000 square feet smaller than the typical Supercenter. That’s akin to retail culture shock for consumers who associate Wal-Mart with size and breadth of product offerings. In January, Wal-Mart said it would close all 102 of its Express stores as part of a total of 269 store closures.Although Dollar General looks to capture more business in urban and rural markets with the smaller-format stores, the concept might take a while to have much impact on the overall financial performance."While a smaller format should allow the company to be more flexible with future site selection, given that plans call for just 80 units on a nearly 12,500 store base, we do not expect the decision will have a material impact on performance in the near- to medium-term," RBC Capital Markets analyst Scot Ciccarelli noted in a recent report.The bigger impact will come from Dollar General’s aggressive plan to open a total of 900 new stores overall, which would bring the total store count to more than 13,000. That would help it close in on main rival Dollar Tree (DLTR), which currently has about 13,600 stores.Dollar Tree more than doubled its size following last year's $10 billion buyout of Family Dollar Stores, which closed in July. That deal brought Dollar Tree 8,100 stores and $2.6 billion in annual sales, and came after a failed bid by Dollar General to acquire Family Dollar.Dollar General still ranks No. 1 in sales, however. It logged $20.4 billion in revenue during fiscal 2015, which ended in January. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect sales this fiscal year to reach $22.4 billion. Dollar Tree took in $15.5 billion in revenue last fiscal year and is expected to record about $21 billion this year.Meanwhile, Dollar General also has produced better bottom-line growth. While Dollar Tree has reported lower year-over-year earnings each of the last three quarters, Dollar General has strung together six straight quarters of double-digit EPS gains.Dollar General’s steady growth is the product of both internal initiatives and macro trends, Ciccarelli said: "We believe the company has broadened its customer base through a combination of low prices and conveniently located stores, helped by economic necessity on the part of U.S. consumers and a reduction in the pre-recession social stigma that surrounded shopping at dollar stores."The company earned $1.30 a share during the fiscal 2015 fourth quarter, up 11% from the prior year and above consensus estimates for $1.26. Revenue gained 7% to $5.29 billion, slightly above views for $5.28 billion. Same-store sales climbed 2.2%, in line with consensus.The company’s sales per square foot reached $226 during 2015, up from $223 the prior year. As recently as 2008, Dollar General had sales per square foot of less than $160, JPMorgan analyst Matthew Boss noted in a report.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Dollar General to grow earnings 15% this fiscal year and another 12% next year.Boss says growth in the metric has been driven by internal initiatives such as expanding the size of Dollar General’s coolers, tweaking its apparel and home goods lineups, and selling beer and wine in some stores."In addition, the combination of an aging baby boomer population and higher income demographic has placed the company in a sweet spot for traffic," Boss wrote.

In many parts of small-town America, big shopping trips for basic necessities can take over an afternoon. Maybe there’s a drive of a half-hour or more to Wal-Mart (WMT), then the epic journey across an airfield-sized parking lot and through a massive store to a long checkout line. But if you need just a few items for dinner that night,…

Calvert Equity Portfolio follows what it calls a "responsible" path of investing, while also controlling risk and seeking market-leading stocks.It sounds like a challenging juggling act. But the$2.1 billion mutual fund has been relatively successful lately. In the year ended going into Tuesday, Calvert Equity gained 2.12% as its large-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. averaged a 1.80% loss and the S&P 500 gained 2.15%. That put the fund ahead of 88% of its peers.It's beaten 89% of its direct rivals so far this year. The fund's 12.09% average annual gain over the past three years topped 55% of its peers, which averaged 11.67%. The S&P 500's average annual gain was 12.15%.The fund, managed by Richard England since 2006 and since 2015 by Lance Garrison, Joseph Hudepohl, Jeffrey Miller and Robert Walton, carries an IBD 36-Month Performance Rating of A.Through responsible investment principles, Calvert aims to help investors and entrepreneurs create a better world, as founding Chairman D. Wayne Silby put it in the fund's latest annual report to investors.The fund aims to control risk by seeking established companies with a history of steady, sustainable earnings growth, which are favorably priced.Facebook (FB) is a name that has helped buoy the fund for the past year. Shares are up 37% over the past 12 months. Earnings per share grew 16%, 33% and 46% the past three quarters.On Tuesday, shares were trading lower for a second straight day. Rival Twitter announced that it had beaten Facebook and others for the right to live-stream the National Football League's "Thursday Night Football."Trading at around 112, Facebook shares are forming a lopsided base with a buy point at 117.69.The stock has IBD's Composite Rating of 99. The Composite Rating combines IBD’s five performance ratings, including EPS and Relative Strength ratings.Ross Stores (ROST), another stock with a 99 Comp Rating, is up 13% over the past 12 months.Trading near 58, shares are within the 5% buy range from a 55.74 buy point.Ross is the largest U.S. discount apparel chain. Fourth-quarter earnings per share rose 10% to 66 cents. That beat Wall Street expectations. Q4 sales rose 7%, which also beat estimates. But full-year guidance lagged expectations amid plans to increase wages and a cloudy retail environment.Dollar General (DG), a newcomer to the portfolio since Sept. 30, is up 20% so far this year. That's the biggest gainer in the portfolio this year.The discount merchandiser is a defensive play in a slow-growth economy. Also, average annual earnings per share growth was 15% the past five years.Trading around 85, the stock's three-weeks-tight pattern offers a potential new entry at 86.90.Aon (AON) is the second-biggest share-price gainer in the portfolio so far this year, up 14%.The insurance products broker sports a 90 Comp Rating. EPS grew 20% in Q4, up from a 4% decline the prior stanza.Shares pulled back on Tuesday along with the broad market. In midafternoon they were trading just below their March 29 breakout price of 102.68. Volume was below average.Among other holdings, Accenture (ACN) is up 11% so far this year.EPS for the consulting-services provider and IT outsourcer grew 3%, 6%, 5% and 24% in the past four frames. The stock has a modest C- Accumulation/Distribution Rating, which is often a sign of selling by institutional investors.Trading around 114, share price is at the top of its buy range from a 109.96 flat-base buy point.

Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) late Wednesday reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share excluding one-time items, beating analysts' consensus by three cents a share and pushing shares up late Wednesday.The retail closeout chain said that its revenue rose 21% to $243.4 million, topping views for $239.1 million and accelerating from 16% in its fiscal Q3.For the current fiscal year, which ends Jan. 28, 2017, Ollie's guided sales of $865 million to $875 million, the midpoint of which is below analysts' consensus for $872.3 million. It expects 83-85 cents EPS, vs. views for 76 cents. "We feel very good about the current outlook and trends across our business," CEO Mark Butler said in a written statement. But it sees same-store sales growth of just 1.5%-2.5% after a 5% jump in Q4.Ollie's stock rose 5.7% to 22.99 in late trading. Shares closed up 0.9% to 22.70 on the stock market today, retaking a 22.63 buy point. But the after-hours action suggests that the stock may be out of the buy range limit of 23.76.The stock initially broke out on March 18 but undercut its buy area on Tuesday.The company opened three new stores during the quarter, ending with a total of 203 outlets in 17 states. It expects to add 28-32 stores this year and doesn't plan to close any outlets.Ollie's joined Dollar General (DG), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Big Lots (BIG) and Five Below (FIVE) as a publicly traded company last summer after pricing at 16 and launching trading on July 16 in its initial public offering.The discounter is in the Retail & Discount Variety group, ranked an excellent 4 on IBD's list of 197 industries. Dollar General closed down 0.1% Wednesday, Dollar Tree rose 0.7%, and direct rival Big Lots rose 0.6%. Five Below, which is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, advanced 0.5%.

A slimmed-down Sector Leaders screen showed two retailers and a homebuilder on Thursday. The screen has been a lot smaller than normal in recent weeks -- not because of an unhealthy market, but because few stocks meet the stringent fundamental criteria needed to make the screen. The retail sector is a big one in IBD’s database, made up of 18…

Dollar General (DG) shares bumped up past their buy point Thursday as the dollar-store chain's candy and snacks, perishables, tobacco and food departments experienced the "most significant" sales increases in the fourth quarter.Earnings grew 11% to $1.30 per share on 7% revenue growth to $5.29 billion, ahead of consensus views for $1.26 earnings per share and $5.28 billion in revenue.Shares shot up past their buy point of 76.85 on the report after developing a cup-with-handle base for the last eight months, and closed up 10.7% to 83.23."At first glance we were impressed by Dollar General's better-than-expected Q4 '15 results, which were consistent with our view that the company remains the 'least risky' way of gaining exposure to the deep-discount retailing space," wrote BB&T Capital Markets analyst Anthony Chukumba in a brief note Thursday morning, prior to the earnings call.Dollar General's Q4 same-store sales growth of 2.2% was in line with Chukumba's estimate. Reuters cited Consensus Metrix analysts as expecting a 1.9% rise.In keeping with the company's newly established long-term growth model, it is broadly targeting 7%-10% annual net sales growth and a 10%-15% rise in diluted earnings per share every year. Wall Street is anticipating 9% sales growth and a 13% EPS rise for the year.Dollar General said it approved on Tuesday a 14% boost to its regular quarterly cash dividend to 25 cents a share. It plans to open 900 new stores in fiscal 2016.Competitor Dollar Tree (DLTR), which recently acquired Family Dollar, fell short of Q4 estimates when it reported at the beginning of the month. Full-year profit guidance also missed views.Dollar Tree's stock rebounded that day to close higher, nearly reaching an 82.86 buy point. But shares drifted lower over the next several sessions until Thursday morning, when they vaulted 4% to 79.82, moving above their 50-day line.RELATED:Discount Retailer Dollar General Offers StabilityDollar Tree Earnings Miss, But Stock Stages Bullish Upside Reversal.

Retail tends to depend on a flourishing economy for its significant moves, but discount and variety retailers don't necessarily have that requirement. People love bargains, no matter what. Of IBD's 197 industry groups, the discount and variety retailers have been moving up sharply. Two months ago, the group was at No. 97; a month ago, it was at No. 62; and now, it…

Large-cap growth mutual funds have lagged their large-cap value counterparts so far this year. But large-cap growth funds have outperformed over the past decade.The reasons for the outperformance are worth bearing in mind whenever you make buy or sell decisions in your portfolio, especially the diversified portion -- your mutual funds and ETFs. Knowing the reasons for the decade's worth of outperformance could help lubricate your funds' forward motion.Growth funds lagged this year and early in the decade -- especially during the 2008-09 financial crisis downturn. But the ballgame has largely gone to large-cap growth funds since late 2010.Since the start of 2006 through March 11, large-cap growth funds averaged a yearly gain of 6.79% vs. 5.38% for large-cap value funds, according to Morningstar Inc.If you had invested $10,000 on Dec. 31, 2005, in large-cap growth funds, your money would have grown into $19,826 by March 11.But if you had invested in large-cap value funds instead, your $10,000 would have expanded into only $17,828.If you have invested, say, $100,000 at the outset, that would be a $20,000 advantage for the large-cap growth route. That would be a nice help to any portfolio, and a nice tailwind for your retirement planning in particular.In the past decade plus this quarter, the top performing large-cap growth fund with $100 million or more in assets is $5.4 billion Alger Spectra Fund (SPECX). The fund averaged an 11.07% yearly gain.As of Dec. 31, 2015, the fund had 90% of its money at work in U.S. stocks and 5% in foreign stocks. The balance was in cash.The fund had 49% of its assets in giant-cap stocks, 28% in large caps, 19% in midcaps and the rest in small caps.The fund's biggest sector was technology, with a 31% weighting. Health care was the next largest sector; it had a 21% weighting. Consumer cyclical was next at 19%. No other sector cracked a double-digit weighting.Recent holdings include Dollar General (DG). The stock is up 18% so far this year. Thursday, Friday and as-of early Monday afternoon, the stock was setting new all-time highs.It gapped up on Thursday when it released fiscal fourth-quarter 2015 results. Many investors saw Dollar's 11% earnings per share gain as a sign that the Q4 woes of other retailers like Wal-Mart (WMT) were company-specific and not signs of trouble for all retailers.Dollar also raised its quarterly dividend by 14% to 25 cents a share.The stock has a very strong 97 Composite Rating from IBD. The Composite Rating combines IBD’s five stock-performance ratings, including EPS and RS Ratings, with 99 being the highest.Spirit Airlines (SAVE) is up 20% so far this year, though still 41% below its 52-week high.Spirit, which has a strong 87 Comp Rating, has seen its EPS fly higher by 13%, 34% and 27% the past three quarters.The low-fare airline has gotten a lift from low fuel costs and rising passenger numbers. The airline has added new routes.Coach (COH) is up 21% so far this year, although it has posted nine straight quarters of EPS declines. Still, its fiscal Q2 earnings of 68 cents a share beat Wall Street expectations of 67 cents a share.The leather-goods retailer has a so-so Comp Rating of 74.On March 14, RBC Capital Markets analysts raised their price target to 42 from 38. RBC said Coach saw a "meaningful pickup in number of" shoppers over the past six months.Analysts expect earnings to rise 14% in the fiscal third quarter ending March 31. They're seen down 1% for the full year but rising 11% the following year.

A quiet day of trading Monday saw stocks finish mixed and mostly unchanged after the Easter holiday. The Dow added 0.1%, the S&P 500 rose less than 0.1% and the Nasdaq eased 0.1%. Volume fell from Thursday’s light levels. European stock markets were closed Monday, which probably had something to do with it. The Russell 2000 and IBD 50 each…

Stocks kicked off the week with a quiet performance Monday, holding small gains in early afternoon trading.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each rose 0.2%. The Nasdaq added 0.1%. Volume on both exchanges was tracking below Thursday's pre-holiday levels. Advancing stocks had a slight edge over decliners on the NYSE, while it was the opposite situation on the Nasdaq.In economic news, new data from the Commerce Department showed that income gains continued to decelerate in February. Meanwhile, GDP data Friday showed that the economy grew at a faster rate in Q4 than initially reported.In the stock market today, Starwood (HOT) picked up 2% after China-based Anbang trumped a revised offer from Marriott (MAR) to acquire Starwood. Shares of Marriott jumped 4%.Other gainers included Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA). The company's class A shares added 0.8% to 212,300 after UBS initiated coverage of the Warren Buffett-led company with a buy rating and set a 244,500 price target.In the retail space, Dollar General (DG) outperformed, rising more than 2%. It completed a three-weeks-tight pattern last week, a bullish structure to watch for a breakout.Inside the IBD 50, MaxLinear (MXL) recovered nicely after a volatile session Thursday, with its shares rising 3%. The stock on Thursday erased a double-digit gain from a 16.29 double-bottom buy point. A 17.85 buy point, however, is still in play.In the building sector, volume stayed light in Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS) as shares rose 0.6%. It's near the high end of a buy range from a 52.70 cup-with-handle buy point. Earnings and sales growth has accelerated for three straight quarters.On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for May delivery lost nearly 1% to $39.11 a barrel. The 10-year Treasury yield eased 3 basis points to 1.87%.

Oilfield service providers Schlumberger (SLB) and Baker Hughes (BHI) had their price targets hiked Monday, and UBS started Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) with a buy rating.Barclays raised Schlumberger's price target to 83 from 74 and boosted Baker Hughes to 54 from 50.Last week, Schlumberger said it sees first-quarter revenue falling 15% on spending cuts. Meanwhile, Baker Hughes and Halliburton (HAL) keep hitting roadblocks from European and U.S. antitrust regulators in getting their merger approved.Schlumberger shares closed up 0.3% in the stock market today. Baker Hughes lost 1.8%, and Halliburton dipped 0.4%.UBS started Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway's class A shares with a buy rating and a $244,500 price target. Shares rose 0.8%. Meanwhile, the more widely traded B class shares of Berkshire (BRKB) have risen nearly 14% since a Jan. 25 low and also rose 0.8% Monday.Dollar General's (DG) price target was raised to 110 from 90 by Stifel. Last week, Dollar General announced plans to expand its test of its smaller-format stores this year. Shares rallied 2.5%.Finish Line (FINL) was upgraded to buy by Monness Crespi Hardt and BB&T Capital. On Thursday, Finish Line reported strong Q4 results, but guided fiscal 2017 low. Shares jumped 12.2% Monday.

Stocks showed decent gains in the early going Thursday, but strength was short-lived despite news of more stimulus out of Europe.The Nasdaq lost 0.3%, recovering nicely from a 1.4% intraday loss. The Dow Jones industrial average fell less than 0.1%,while the S&P 500 rose less than 0.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Wednesday’s levels. If it holds, it would be distribution day No. 3 for the Nasdaq.The European Central Bank cut its overnight lending rate to zero from 0.5%, increased its monthly asset purchases by one-third and also expanded its asset buys to include corporate bonds as well as sovereign government debt. The ECB’s moves came a week ahead of the Federal Reserve’s policy meeting March 15-16. According to CME Group FedWatch, the odds of a rate hike are 0%.European markets didn’t take too kindly to the news. Germany’s DAX slumped 2.3%, London’s FTSE lost 1.8% and the Paris CAC-40 gave up 1.7%.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) soared 11% in Thursday's after-hours session after reporting another strong quarter.Gold and steel stocks outperformed again in the regular session. April gold settled at $1,272.80 an ounce, up $15.40, or 1.2%. The SPDR Gold Trust (GLD), which tracks the physical price of gold, gained nearly 2%. It closed just above a 120.94 buy point. Meanwhile, U.S. Steel (X) led the Steel-Producers group to a 3% gain. Shares jumped nearly 15%.A few other stocks  bucked the trend.Dollar General (DG) gapped out of a cup-with-handle base with a 76.85 buy point after reporting strong earnings before the open. Shares soared nearly 11%.Broadcom (AVGO) added to gains after a recent breakout over a 138.79 double-bottom buy point. Shares rose close to 2%. Broadcom is fast approaching a recent high of 149.72. The chip performer was the second-best gainer in the IBD 50, behind TAL Education (XRS), which rose nearly 4%.On the downside, Twitter (TWTR) slumped 6% after a published report said the company is doling out restricted stock and cash bonuses to hold on to staff.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, April crude oil settled at $37.84 a barrel, down 45 cents, or 1.2%. Meanwhile, the 10-year Treasury yield added 5 basis points to 1.93%. The yield has soared 21 basis points since its Feb. 26 close at 1.72%.

Downside reversals were dominant in Thursday’s new-high list after morning gains faded, but the session did yield a few solid breakouts. Cantel Medical (CMN) gained 2.53 to 69.62 after reporting strong earnings before the open. It cleared a 68.68 buy point. The maker of infection prevention and control products has one of the most consistent track record of earnings growth…

A morning rally fueled by interest rate cuts in Europe faded going into the lunch hour Thursday, sending stocks lower.The Nasdaq fell 0.7%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average was off 0.6% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking higher than the same time Wednesday on both exchanges.The European Central Bank lowered interest rates and increased quantitative easing. Its benchmark interest rate was cut to zero from 0.05%, and its deposit rate dropped to -0.4% from -0.3%. But ECB President Mario Draghi said he doesn't see future rate cuts, damping enthusiasm.The euro dropped early on the news, then rose 1.5% against the dollar, trading above $1.11. The 10-year Treasury note fell, pushing yields to 1.94%, up about 5 basis points. Oil was about 2% lower, trading below $38 a barrel. The dollar index fell 1%.Box (BOX) rallied 3% after reporting smaller-than-expected loss. The company said it lost 26 cents a share during Q4 vs. analysts' expectations of a 29-cent loss. They issued an upbeat forecast even though they are expected to lose money this year and next. The stock was well off morning highs.Dollar General (DG) was another bright spot, gapping up and breaking out of a cup-with-handle base. The company reported earnings of $1.30 a share, beating the consensus estimate of $1.26. Same-store sales rose 2.2%.Canadian Solar (CSIQ) dimmed by 11% after reporting earnings that beat estimates, but offered revenue and earnings guidance below the Street.

The ECB’s moves came a week ahead of the Federal Reserve’s policy meeting March 15-16. The SPDR Gold Trust (GLD), which tracks the physical price of gold, gained nearly 2%. It closed just above a 120.94 buy point.A few other stocks  bucked the trend.Dollar General (DG) gapped out of a cup-with-handle base with a 76.85 buy point after reporting strong earnings before the open. Shares soared nearly 11%.Broadcom (AVGO) added to gains after a recent breakout over a 138.79 double-bottom buy point. Shares rose close to 2%. The maker of infection prevention and control products has one of the most consistent track record of earnings growth, with several quarters in a row of double-digit earnings and sales growth.On the downside, Twitter (TWTR) slumped 6% after a published report said the company is doling out restricted stock and cash bonuses to hold on to staff.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, April crude oil settled at $37.84 a barrel, down 45 cents, or 1.2%. Biogen (BIIB) got a lower price target Friday following bad news about its best-selling drug, while software security firms FireEye (FEYE) and Symantec (SYMC) got positive analyst moves, and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) price target was raised.Baird lowered its price target on Biogen to 268 from 316 and maintained its neutral rating on the stock. On Thursday, an analyst at Cowen & Co. said that a European court revoked a patent on Biogen’s multiple-sclerosis drug Tecfidera,the biotech’s biggest moneymaker. Biogen officials said the firm will appeal the decision, according to news reports Friday morning.Biogen shares climbed 3.1% to 259.74 on the stock market today. The stock is 46% off its March 20, 2015 peak, but it really broke down starting in late July.FireEye’s price target was raised to 18 by Baird, which maintained its neutral rating on the stock. Earlier this week, the security software firm said it expects to see profits in 2017 amid a transition to a software-as-a-service subscription model. Shares rose back above their 50-day line on Feb. 29, ending an 8-month run below that level.FireEye shares rose 4.6% to 18.27.Fellow security software maker Symantec climbed 3.9% to 18.39 after it was upgraded to outperform from sector perform by RBC Capital Markets, which has a 23 price target on the stock. Symantec  is at its best levels since last August, breaking a downtrend that started in January 2015. Shares soared through their 200-day line this week.Meanwhile, another security software firm, Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), was initiated at underperform with a 65 price target. Check Point shares rose 0.1% to 83.Shares of Ulta Beauty soared 17.3% to 191.62, rocketing to a new high Friday. Ulta's price target was hiked to 215 from 210 by Telsey Advisory Group, which has an outperform rating on the stock. Late Thursday, the beauty products retailer topped earnings views and offered full-year revenue and earnings guidance above consensus.Dollar General's (DG) price target was raised to 89 from 83 at Telsey Advisory Group, which rates the stock an outperform. Dollar General's stock rose 2.1% to 85.01, hitting another high.Shares of the deep discount retailer popped 11% to a new closing high of 83.23 on Thursday  after it topped quarterly earnings views and offered upbeat guidance for this year.

The market is back in an uptrend, but the S&P 500 is still trading below its high from May. It is easy to see eight months of a struggling market reflected in IBD’s blue chip Big Cap 20 list. Fully 14 stocks on the current list qualify as defensive names.Utilities including Southern Energy (SO), Consolidated Edison (ED) and WEC Energy Group (WEC) are defensive because their prices to consumers are generally locked, and customers have little choice but to use the product. Also, the stocks typically offer healthy dividends.Another factor: Utilities are a segment into which mutual funds working to maintain minimum levels of investment rotate into during choppy markets. This demand can hold share prices steady or even drive them higher while the general market corrects.On the other hand, four stocks on the list qualify as solid growth stocks: Cognizant Technologies (CTSH),  Equinix (EQIX) and Intuitive Surgical (ISRG).McDonald’s (MCD) carries some combined traits of defensive and growth stocks, giving it an interesting leg up in the current market. The fast-food chain’s turnaround under new Chief Executive Steve Easterbrook has made the stock a growth contender with regard to a number of fundamental and technical attributes: earnings growth, same-store-sales, relative strength and accumulation/distribution.McDonald’s still falls short on the standard punch list of CAN SLIM elements. But the turnaround has made the stock much more attractive for investors looking for healthy dividend names and/or double-threat defensive plays.McDonald’s, which fell off the list Monday, was extended after last week’s bounce off its 10-week moving average, and from a breakout in October.Dollar General (DG) was a double-threat growth/defensive stock from its re-entry to public markets in November 2009 through July 2012. It and its now-merged competitors Family Dollar and Dollar Tree (DLTR) were grabbing market share from Wal-Mart (WMT) and buying up smaller, regional chains across the U.S. Dollar General’s EPS growth is forecast at a healthy 13% for the year ended in January, and 15% in 2017. Revenue growth has slowed to high single digits.O’Reilly Automotive (ORLY) torqued up nearly 1290% from October 2008 to October 2015. During that period, when the market was choppy or in a correction, auto parts chains were seen as dual growth/defensive plays because they were consolidating and gaining market share while benefiting from consumers holding on to their cars longer than they had in the past.O’Reilly, which announces its Q4 results on Feb. 10, is forecast to remain in the camp through 2015 with full EPS growth forecasts of 24%. Revenue growth is seen slowing to 8%. For 2016, analyst consensus puts EPS growth at 14% and sales growth at 7%.Big Cap 20 stocks tend to be stable, healthy performers, but they are not a list of pick-and-play buy opportunities. Investors need to look carefully at the fundamentals and make sure they understand both the company and its value proposition. Sudden changes in market direction can generate significant changes in the companies on the list.

Five leading big-cap stocks are showing strength during the correction. All boast rising relative strength lines, which indicate that they're outperforming the market. Also, stocks whose relative strength lines are rising as they work on new bases have the best chance of breaking out when the market's uptrend resumes. Campbell Soup (CPB) is just shy of a 55.18 buy point…

Warmer weather, online shopping and heavy discounting have made retail a tough space to be in right now, but at least five stocks on the IBD 50 list are bucking the trends.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) has held off Amazon (AMZN) better than its retail peers, partly because of the experiential nature of buying beauty products and partly because of the dedicated customer loyalty that companies like Ulta and Sephora have built, according to analysts.Notably, specialty beauty retailers have the benefit of not being in a seasonal industry, say experts, which means that they are not subject to the promotional pressures that department stores and clothing retailers face.Ulta, a member of IBD's Retail-Specialty industry group, has risen 35% over the last year. The group has collectively lost 6%.Nike (NKE) and Under Armour (UA) have also fared well amid a struggling retail backdrop as "athleisure" continues to make its way out of the gym and into offices and even major fashion houses.Health and wellness trends -- think juice bars, cleanses and the much-anticipated SoulCycle (SCYL) IPO -- have worked in both companies' favor, and Under Armour's push into wearable technology has inserted itself into the tech conversation alongside Fitbit (FIT) and the Apple (AAPL) Watch.Nike's stock has climbed 31% and Under Armour has grown 17% since Jan. 29, 2015. Shares of the Apparel-Shoes and Relating Manufacturing group and Apparel-Clothing Manufacturing have risen 5% and declined 15%, respectively.Both companies are not the only two activewear companies on the list. Foot Locker (FL), which carries both Nike and Under Armour in its stores, also made the cut.Starbucks (SBUX), for its part, isn't afraid of a slowdown in China. The java giant is expanding assertively into the country, with a goal of operating 3,400 stores there by 2019.Starbucks missed Q1 revenue and guided Q2 below consensus estimates when it reported on Jan. 21, but CEO Howard Schultz expressed enthusiasm about bringing Starbucks' mobile-order-and-pay feature to Chinese consumers. He anticipates that it will be a "runaway success."Domestically, its mobile efforts have yielded success, with over a fifth of all U.S. transactions now made via smartphone.Starbucks shares have grown 36% while IBD's Retail-Restaurants group has tumbled 15%.Ross Stores (ROST) doesn't even have an e-commerce presence, but the chain of off-price stores has been labeled "un-Amazonable" by Cowen analyst Oliver Chen, citing the appeal of the "treasure hunt" experience that compels shoppers to visit brick-and-mortar stores.Amid a shift to off-price retailers, analysts agree that there's room for square-footage growth as Ross expands into other regions stateside.Ross Stores' stock has risen 20% over the last year, compared to the Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group, which has declined 14%.A number of other consumer stocks abound on the IBD 50 list, including energy-drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST), discounters Five Below (FIVE) and Dollar General (DG), and baby-clothing merchant Carter's (CRI).RELATED:Why Under Armour’s Market Share May Be Bigger Than You ThinkThink We’re In A Recession? Consider Facebook, Starbucks StockWhy Amazon Has Been Powerless Against Beauty Stores.

Stocks fell sharply again near midday Friday, hurt by more weakness in China stocks overnight and another sharp drop in oil prices. The Nasdaq plunged 3%, the S&P 500 gave up 2.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.2%.
The Shanghai composite index lost another 3.5% overnight, andWest Texas Intermediate crude oil futures plummeted 5% to $29.63 a barrel.

In the stock market today, Wal-Mart (WMT) made headlines among the Dow components, but selling pressure was muted. Shares fell just over 1% after the company announced plans to close 269 stores around the world, including 154 U.S. locations. Of the 154 U.S. locations, 102 are the company's "Express" format stores.

On the earnings front, Intel (INTC) slumped 9% despite reporting better-than-expected Q4 results late Thursday. Q1 revenue guidance was the problem. Weakness in Intel spilled over into several chip names in the Nasdaq 100. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), Lam Research (LRCX), Nvidia (NVDA) and Micron (MU) all fell 6% or more.
In economic news, December retail sales fell 0.1%, slightly below expectations for flat sales. Excluding autos, sales fell 0.1%, well below forecasts for a 0.3% rise.
Constellation Brands (STZ) and Dollar General (DG) were among a handful of gainers, rising 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively.
