Dollar General also early Thursday announced a $1 billion stock buyback, boosting its program to $1.2 billion total, and…

Stock indexes coasted to big gains Friday, but volume retreated for the fourth time in five sessions. The Nasdaq popped 1.9%, while the S&P 500 added 1.6%. The small-cap S&P 600 outperformed with a 2.1% gain. The IBD 50 advanced 2%. Volume fell on both major exchanges. After bulking up weekly volume for three weeks, trade fell last week on the…

U.S. stocks held near session highs Friday heading into the last hour of the regular trading session.The Nasdaq led with a 1.5% advance, the S&P 500 rose 1.3%, and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.1%. Volume was lower across the board vs. the same time Thursday. The major market indexes were on track to extend their gains for a fourth straight week.Winners swamped losers by more than a 4-1 ratio on the NYSE and by about 3-to-1 on the Nasdaq. Only 2 of the Dow's 30 stocks were lower.Oil stocks led the upside in the stock market today, as West Texas Intermediate crude prices rose 2% to $38.70 a barrel. Specialty retail and hospitals also outperformed.The specialty retail group got a boost from Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which vaulted more than 16% to a new high, clearing a 188.58 buy point in heavy trade. The stock gapped up past its 50-day and 200-day moving average lines. After the close Thursday, the beauty store operator reported quarterly earnings that topped views and guided full-year EPS and revenue above consensus estimates. Telsey Advisory Group on Friday boosted its price target to 215 from 210.Airlines lifted more than 2% to regain their 200-day moving average. Alaska Air Group (ALK) soared 5%, clearing a 78.59 cup-with-handle buy point in higher-than-normal volume. Among other carriers, Southwest Airlines (LUV) rose 3%, and IBD 50 stock Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) picked up 2% to retake its 50-day line.Also in the IBD 50, Dollar General (DG) added 2% to a new high in fast turnover, following up on Thursday's 11% jump. Shares are now 10% extended past a 76.85 cup-with-handle buy point cleared Thursday, after the discount retailer's Q4 earnings beat views. Telsey Advisory Group raised its price target to 89 from 83.

U.S. stocks pared losses going into the last hour of the regular trading session Thursday after European Central Bank President Mario Draghi said he doesn't expect future rate cuts.The Nasdaq fell 0.9% while the Dow Jones industrial average and  S&P 500 each gave up 0.6%. Volume was tracking higher across the board vs. the same time Wednesday. Losers outpaced winners by a 7-3 margin on the NYSE and Nasdaq.The biggest decliners included automaker, solar and biotech stocks. Oil stocks lagged, too, as West Texas intermediate crude prices slipped 1% to $37.89 a barrel.Most automakers were lower as new-car sales fell 1.5% in February vs. the same month last year. That marked the first monthly drop in six months. Volkswagen (VLKAY) fell 2%, Daimler (DDAIF) 2% and Ford Motor (F) 1%. Tesla (TSLA) skidded 3% after staging a downward reversal.In the IBD 50, LGI Homes (LGIH) fell 5% in fast volume, giving up half of  Wednesday's gain. The stock turned south after hitting resistance at its 200-day line. Shares jumped in extended trading Wednesday after the homebuilder reported Q4 earnings that beat forecasts.Other IBD 50 stocks taking big hits included AMN Healthcare Services (AHS), down 6%, and Universal Display (OLED), which gave up 4%.Gold miners, discount retailers and steel stocks were among the few industry group gainers. Dollar General (DG) gapped up and soared 8% to a new high, clearing a 76.85 cup-with-handle buy point in heavy trade. The discount store operator reported Q4 results that topped views. Same-store sales rose 2%.

Stocks rolled out moderate gains early Thursday, though an early flourish that followed a key move by the European Central Bank faded.The Dow and S&P 500 added 0.3% each. The Nasdaq grabbed a 0.5% gain.Volume rose sharply as the stock market today received early boosts from the European Central Bank's broad upshift in economic stimulus and a better-than-expected U.S. weekly jobless claims report.Even so, Europe's markets pulled well off their early gains to trade narrowly mixed in afternoon action.More than two-thirds of the Dow's stocks traded higher at the starting bell. Intel (INTC) jumped highest, with a 1% gain. Exxon-Mobil (XOM) dropped to the bottom of the list, down 1.2%.Oil and gas-related stocks took the 10 worst losses on the S&P 500, as oil prices eased slightly but remained up by 6% (West Texas Intermediate) and 9% (Brent crude) so far this week.Gold mining stocks rumbled higher, buoyed by a reversal in gold prices, trading up 0.3% at $1,261 an ounce. Anglogold Ashanti (AU) and Sibanye Gold (SBGL) surged 5% each.Dollar General (DG) stacked up a 6% gain, breaking out above a 76.85 buy point after a solid Q4 report. Earnings and revenue narrowly topped analyst expectations, while management hoisted the company's quarterly dividend 14% and announced plans to buy back $1 billion worth of shares during 2016. The gain put the IBD 50 stock at the top of a buy range, almost 5% above the buy point.Dollar General's momentum was infectious, lifting Dollar Tree (DLTR) nearly 5%. Five Below (FIVE) rose 2% to trade just below a 39.62 buy point in a nine-month cup with handle base.Online travel broker Expedia (EXPE) rattled off a 4% gain after an upgrade to overweight from neutral by Piper Jaffray, which also lifted the stock's price target to 140 from 130. Expedia shares are back above their 10-week moving average, climbing the right side of a four-month consolidation.Smith & Wesson (SWHC) slipped more than 1% in hefty trade. The stocks remains up 3% for the week and a shade less than 5% above a 26.64 cup base buy point.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Dollar Tree (DLTR) reported mixed results Tuesday — beating sales views but falling short on earnings — as the deep discount retailer's top line benefited from its buyout of Family Dollar but its bottom line was negatively impacted by the deal. Wall Street didn't seem to mind the earnings miss, though. Dollar Tree shares shot higher as investors cheered the…

Strong quarterly results from Wal-Mart and TJX helped ease concerns Tuesday that U.S. consumers are in full retreat, though they continue to shy away from clothes shopping and hunt for the best deals.

TJX (TJX) topped estimates and raised its guidance going into the all-important holiday quarter, and the off-price retailer doesn't appear to be burdened by the same inventory and pricing issues that plague full-price peers.In contrast to Macy's (M) and Nordstrom's (JWN) weak results and forecasts last week, TJX lifted its full-year same-store sales growth estimate to 4%-5% from a prior outlook for 3%-4% growth. Q3 earnings edged up over 1% to 86 cents per share, topping by 2 cents, and revenue grew over 5% to $7.75 billion, vs. views for $7.73 billion."It's a broader reflection of core middle- and lower-income consumers, which makes up 70% of the population," Retail Metrics' Ken Perkins told IBD. "They are looking for value."TJX shares climbed 3.85%, and Wal-Mart gained 3.5%.Fourth-quarter and full-year guidance fell short of expectations, however, as the company accounted for a variety of factors — including its late October acquisition of Australian off-pricer Trade Secret — that should weigh on EPS growth by 9%.Meanwhile, Wal-Mart (WMT) saw a 14% drop in Q3 EPS to 99 cents, topping by a penny. Revenue dipped 1.3% to $117.4 billion, missing views, but U.S. comps grew for the fifth straight quarter amid turnaround efforts.Shift In Spending HabitsA "healthy U.S. consumer backdrop," cleaner stores and upgraded staffing, among other factors, will likely drive holiday demand at Wal-Mart, noted Cowen & Co.'s Oliver Chen, who has a market perform rating on the stock.But Wal-Mart still faces competition from Amazon (AMZN), said Perkins, and the big-box retailer is also feeling the heat from dollar stores like Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR).Weighing on traditional retailers and department stores is a shift in spending habits. Perkins pointed to off-pricers' post-recession success as a reason why Macy's, Nordstrom and other companies are pursuing the discount space themselves, with offshoots like Macy's Backstage, Nordstrom Rack and Saks Off Fifth, among others.And in an increasingly cutthroat shopping environment that pits brick-and-mortar shops against Amazon and other online shopping destinations, the battle is being fought on several fronts.But shoppers also aren't as interested in apparel, say both Perkins and Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar. Those dollars are going into a variety of different areas, including home goods and bigger-ticket items such as automotive needs.Outside of cheaper products, another advantage that off-pricers like TJX and Ross Stores (ROST) have is faster and higher inventory turnover, giving it a flexibility that makes it more akin to fast-fashion favorites Forever 21 and Zara than Macy's or Nordstrom."The ones that are outperforming right now are the ones that are most responsive to what consumers want," Weishaar said.Traditional retailers have a six- to nine-month lead time for orders, she explained, while off-pricers can buy merchandise much closer to the start of each season. This helps to "weatherproof" against factors such as, say, a warmer fall that keeps shoppers enjoying the changing foliage instead of shopping for snow boots.When asked about the impact of warm weather — which several other retailers have blamed in recent earnings reports — TJX CEO Carol Meyrowitz said that she'd "rather not talk about weather," focusing instead on her team's performance."That's all about execution and delivering the right product to the right stores at the right time," she said on the post-earnings call. "Every year, we learn and we get better at weatherproofing our business. It just comes back to the model — we keep ourselves very flexible."For department stores, improving lead time is easier said than done, said Perkins. "It's like trying to turn around a battleship."The good news for shoppers, at least, is that Santa's likely to deliver plenty of discounts for the holidays.Perkins said he expects the promotional environment to be "comparable, if not even steeper" and potentially more aggressive than last year's holiday quarter, as retailers try to get rid of leftover inventory from the fall.Weishaar was even less optimistic: "It's going to be horrible. It's going to be one of the worst we've seen in a long time."
Retail sales disappoint in September

Retail sales rose just 0.1% last month after an unchanged August. Auto sales were strong, but outside of the sector, sales slid 0.3%, the worst showing since January. Sales were unchanged excluding both autos and gas stations. Cheaper gas prices are hitting gas station revenue, but should be bolstering discretionary income for other spending. Nonstore sales — mostly ecommerce — fell 0.2%. So did electronics and appliance store sales.

Several retailers' stocks fell sharply intraday as Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) announced that earnings in the next fiscal year will fall 6%-12% due to its heavy tech spending, wage increases and weak sales. Wal-Mart shares fell 9.3% to a 3-1/2-year low. Target (TGT) lost 3.7% and Dollar General (DG) 2.9%. But concerns about consumer spending spread further, with Best Buy (BBY) down 5% and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) 4.4%.
Producer prices fall sharply

September's producer price index slid 0.5%, the biggest fall in 8 months and more than the 0.2% drop expected. Wholesale energy prices fell 5.9% after August's 3.3% tumble. But core PPI, which excludes food and energy costs, still retreated 0.3% vs. views for a 0.1% increase. Year over year, wholesale prices fell 1.1%, with core wholesale inflation up 0.8%.
Business inventories flat again

Business stockpiles were flat in August after an unchanged July, revised down from a 0.1% gain. Retail inventories excluding autos, which are part of the GDP calculation, advanced 0.4% after July's 0.3% gain. Sales at all business levels fell 0.6% after July's 0.1% uptick. At the current sales pace, it would take 1.37 months for businesses to clear shelves.
EU industrial production falls

Excluding construction, the European Union's industrial production fell 0.5% in August vs. July, matching views. Monthly output has expanded only once in the past five months. Year over year, growth slowed to a 0.9% gain in August from July's 1.7% gain. That's a four-month low. Analysts expected a gain of 1.8%.

 The U.K. jobless rate hit a 7-year low of 5.4% in the three months to August, the Office for National Statistics said. Workers' total earnings rose 3% from a year earlier, slightly less than expected. The Bank of England is considering rising pay as a factor in when it will raise the U.K.'s interest rates.

Yahoo (YHOO) shares finished lower Wednesday on several price target cuts that followed a weak earnings report, while Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) also had its price target cut, Twitter (TWTR) was downgraded, and VMware (VMW) was hit with a series of downgrades.Yahoo was downgraded to neutral from buy at Mizuho Securities, which also lowered its price target on the stock to 37 from 40. In addition, Axiom Capital lowered its price target on Yahoo to 44 from 45, and RBC Capital Markets cut it to 42 from 47.Late Tuesday, Yahoo missed Q3 earnings and revenue viewsand offered disappointing Q4 revenue guidance. On the upside, it also said it's on track to complete the proposed tax-free spinoff of its 15% stake in China e-commerce leader Alibaba (BABA), and that it reached a three-year agreement with Google, the main unit of Alphabet (GOOGL), to team up in Internet search and advertising.Even so, Yahoo shares closed down 5.2% on the stock market today. Alibaba lost 3.2%, while Alphabet gave up 1.2% a day before its earnings report.Twitter was downgraded to underweight by Morgan Stanley and given a 24 price target — well below other recent price targets on the stock. Twitter shares ended down 5.2%.Chipotle sank 5.7% after Wedbush slashed its price target to 740 from 800 following Tuesday's quarterly profit miss. Although sales rose 12% to $12.2 billion, it was the fourth straight quarter of decelerating growth on the top line.VMware received several downgrades, a day after it beat quarterly EPS and revenue views but offered disappointing Q4 revenue guidance. Maxim Group downgraded the stock to hold from buy and cut its price target to 75 from 100.Monness Crespi & Hardt downgraded VMware to neutral from buy, while Pacific Crest downgraded it to sector weight from overweight. Several other analysts also downgraded the stock.The virtualization-software maker's majority owner, EMC (EMC), is being acquired by Dell in a $67 billion deal. Although many investors wanted EMC to spin off VMware, Dell will retain control. VMWare shares tumbled 19.4%, while EMC lost 6.3%.Verizon Communications (VZ) fell 0.8% after its price target was cut to 53 from 59 at Argus, which maintained its buy rating on the stock.Medical software firm Cerner (CERN) was initiated at market outperform with an 82 price target by Avondale Partners. Its shares finished essentially unchanged.Stifel cut Harley-Davidson's (HOG) price target to 59 from 71 but maintained its buy rating on the stock. Harley shares fell 2.5% after diving 13.9% on Tuesday following weak results.Deep discount retailer Dollar General (DG) rose 0.8% after it was upgraded to neutral by Bank of America. Dollar General's stock price is off about 17% from its high of 81.42 set in July.Yum Brands (YUM) climbed 0.7% after its price target was raised to 87 from 80 by RBC Capital Markets. The owner of the KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut chains said Tuesday it plans to spin off its China operations.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

Five Below (FIVE) shares are sinking after hours after the teen retailer reported weaker-than-expected second-quarter sales figures. Adjusted diluted per-share earnings fell 13% to 13 cents, in line with analyst forecasts. Revenue grew 19.5% to $182.2 million, short of views for $184.7 million. Same-store sales increased 3%. Shares of Five Below sank 11% in after-hours trading on the stock market…

Stocks opened with modest gains Thursday after the European Central Bank broadly increased its stimulus efforts.Premarket futures initially rose 1% on the news, but gains faded by the open after Mario Draghi said he did not anticipate future rate cuts.The Nasdaq added 0.5% while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 picked up 0.3% each.The early impetus for the stock market today came from overseas, where the ECB voted to lower its benchmark interest rate to zero from 0.5%. It also trimmed its bank deposit rate to -0.4%, down from -0.3%. Both moves are meant to spur additional lending. The euro initially fell on the news but turned higher.The central bank also significantly expanded its monthly bond buying initiative to $86.9 billion a month from $65.2 billion, and it expanded the scope of buying to corporate bonds vs. a prior focus on government bonds.Europe's markets upshifted from narrowly mixed trade to broad gains near midsession. Frankfurt's DAX and Paris' CAC 40 led with gains of better than 2%In addition, data showed Ireland's GDP knocked out a 9.2% gain in the fourth quarter, its fastest pace since Q1 2001. For the year, Ireland's economy expanded 7.8%.Economic news in the U.S. was also positive, with jobless claims dropping to 259,000 in the week ended March 5, well below consensus estimates for 272,000. The Labor Department revised its prior week estimate slightly lower, to 277,000 claims. The four-week moving average slipped to 267,500 -- a fifth straight decline.The Treasury Department is scheduled to release February budget data at 2 p.m. ET.The dollar rose steeply. Bonds edged higher, skimming one basis point from the 10-year yield, to 1.86%.Oil ebbed slightly, with West Texas Intermediate trading above $38 and up more than 6% for the week. Gold slipped a fraction to $1,250 an ounce, down more than 1% from Friday's settle.Dow stocks ran higher, led by Nike (NKE), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Intel (INTC), which gained more than 1% each.At the top of the S&P 500 and the IBD 50, Dollar General (DG) commanded a 7% gain early on after reporting Q4 results narrowly above analyst consensus expectations. Management raised its quarterly dividend 14% and announced plans to buy back $1 billion in shares during 2016. The stock ended Wednesday 2% below a 76.85 buy point in an eight-month, cup-with-handle base.Smith & Wesson (SWHC) edged lower in early trade. The firearms maker retook a 26.62 buy point Tuesday, then surged 5% in powerful trade Wednesday, ending the session 8% above that buy mark.Image provided by Shutterstock.

But don’t bother pulling out your credit card: The Fortune 500 company with over 1,200 stores in 33 states doesn’t offer online shopping. To ‘E’ Or Not To ‘E’? Rival TJX Cos. (TJX)…

Few things feel as homey and comfortable to chart readers of the CAN SLIM ilk as cup-with-handle bases.Cup-with-handle bases are common and easy to identify, and often preface powerful rallies. Most cup bases possess a number of basic traits, discussed in Tuesday's column.  They can be as short as seven weeks long. But they are generally longer -- occasionally reaching lengths of a year or more.This time frame can make even a common, familiar base type tricky to spot. The tendency among growth investors is to set aside leading stocks that slump into long-term consolidations. Many of them take years to recover. Others never do.One recent example of a long-term cup was Dollar General (DG), which cleared an eight-month cup with handle on Thursday. Lululemon Athletica (LULU), on the other hand, has been struggling to clear a buy point in a similar, six-month base.A model case was Biogen (BIIB), which crafted a cup-with-handle base throughout most of 2010, when it was called Biogen Idec.The base began late in March. Seven of 12 weeks on its down leg were weekly declines in above-average volume. Yet this action showed institutional investors selling in a controlled rather than panicked fashion. Six of seven weeks on the upside were advances, and four of them occurred in above-average trade. During the last two, trade rose 46% and 57%, respectively, above Biogen’s weekly average.Both of those weeks closed below the midpoint of their weekly ranges. This activity raises a warning flag. But unless other flaws appear, it is not a deal killer for a base. The depth of the base was 24%, well within the 35% maximum limit from intraday high to low for normal cups.The right side of the cup topped out in the weeks that ended July 30 and Aug. 13, 2010. In both weeks, the stock notched a high of 58.16. The handle slipped 9% lower in quiet trade, retesting its converging 10- and 40-week moving averages.A burst of heavy trade shook out the final sellers and left the stock perched atop its 10-week moving average in the week that ended Sept. 24. Biogen traded quietly for a few more weeks. On the day of its breakout past a 58.26 buy point, Biogen held a 92 Composite Rating from IBD. Its EPS Rating was a powerful 96, and its RS rating -- despite nearly seven months of basing -- was an imperfect but still healthy 81. Its Sales, Margins and Return on Equity grade was an A, Accumulation/Distribution a B+.The outcome: a 725% rally over the next 53 months.

Retail stocks have shown improvement this year amid slow but steady growth in jobs and the economy. The retail sector has risen six places since the start of the year, to No. 15 out of 33. Six retailers are in the IBD 50, led by No. 2-ranked Stamps.com (STMP), which is testing resistance at its 10-week moving average ahead of…
Stock futures were up, but had pulled back from early highs ahead of Thursday's open despite a surprise jump in mid-Atlantic region manufacturing.

Dow futures traded 19.8 points above fair market value, down from a 33-point gain an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures held a 16.3-point gain, sticking close to earlier highs. S&P 500 futures pulled back to a 5.3-point gain.

The stock market today carries a bit less weight on its shoulders after the S&P 500 decisively punched past its 50-day moving average and the Nasdaq gained more altitude above that important line of support on Wednesday.

Investors drew confidence after minutes from the Fed's Oct. 28 meeting showed a majority of the Federal Open Market Committee in favor of a rate hike in December. Apple (AAPL) also factored into the day's gains, gapping up to a better-than-3% gain after an upgrade from Goldman Sachs.

The current uptrend still bears a heavy load of distribution days: six on the Nasdaq, five on the S&P 500. That is good cause to keep a cautious stance toward new purchases or stocks flashing sell signals.

A relatively light economic calendar opened with the Labor Department reporting weekly jobless claims eased to 271,000 in the week ended Nov. 14, down from 276,000 in the prior week. Economist consensus had forecast a pullback to 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average continued higher, to 270,750, marking its third straight advance.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve's regional manufacturing survey firmed up for November, rising to 1.9. That beat consensus expectations for a flat outcome. The index fell to a minus 4.5 reading in October following a minus 6 tally in September.
The Conference Board is set to release its leading economic indicators index for October at 10 a.m. ET.

On the Dow, UnitedHealth (UNH) dropped 6% in premarket action. The Minnetonka, Minn.-based managed care provider trimmed its full-year EPS guidance to $6, down from $6.25 to $6.35 and below consensus views for $6.32. The company said claims activity deteriorated and individual participation in insurance exchanges lagged.

Sellers kept up the pressure on retail and apparel makers, sending Best Buy (BBY) down 9% and Perry Ellis (PERY) to a 4% loss after mixed quarterly reports. Buckle (BKE) and Bon-Ton Stores (BONT) reported Q3 earnings misses, although the stocks remained unchanged in premarket trade.

Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) swept ahead 17%, topping the S&P 500 in premarket action. The owner of the K-cup coffee franchise trounced analysts' Q4 earnings expectations. Revenue fell less than forecast, and management boosted the quarterly dividend by 13% to 32.5 cents. Keurig shares ended Wednesday down 75% from a November high.

Salesforce.com (CRM) jabbed up 5% before the bell. A 50% EPS leap and a 24% gain in Q3 revenue narrowly cleared analyst consensus projections. Revenue and earnings projections for Q4 were in line with analyst views, and management hoisted full-year EPS guidance to just above consensus. The software-as-a-service leader ended Wednesday in buying range, a bit more than 1% above a 76.31 cup-base buy point.
Some China-based plays chalked off strong premarket moves.
Ctrip.com International (CTRP) soared 13% higher after delivering its Q3 results. The online travel site ended Wednesday 18% above an 80.30 buy point in a double-bottom base.

China-based micro-blogging site Weibo (WB) shot up 8% in premarket trade. It reported EPS of 10 cents, up from a 1-cent, per-share loss a year ago and above views for 6 cents. Revenue surged a better-than-forecast 48%. Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. Major U.S. index ETFs wobbled Wednesday, opening high for the second consecutive day but paring gains as investors weighed overseas action and Fed comments on rate normalization. Stock ETFs pulled back after a top Federal Reserve official described a September rate hike as "less compelling" now. PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), tracking the tech-laden Nasdaq composite index, popped 2.3% to 100.25 intraday.…

Supervalu (SVU) shares are soaring after the grocery wholesaler and retailer said that it is exploring a sale of its Save-A-Lot business. The company also topped fiscal first-quarter forecasts. Supervalu has almost 3,600 stores, over half of which are part of its food distribution business. There are over 1,300 Save-A-Lot discount grocery stores across the country. After shoring up its position in the hotly competitive discount arena by acquiring a larger rival last year, Dollar Tree faces the task of turning its newly acquired muscle into bigger sales and profits.If it is to be successful, Dollar Tree (DLTR), now the biggest U.S. discount chain, needs to get a better performance from its Family Dollar Store outlets, which were struggling prior to the merger.Wall Street is tentative on Dollar Tree's prospects."There are some natural synergies that came out of the deal with regard to buying and some expenses," Piper Jaffray analyst Peter Keith told Investor's Business Daily. "But the jury is still out on whether Dollar Tree can drive material improvement at the Family Dollar business. At this point, I believe what investors will want to see is better sales productivity from Family Dollar stores, which should in turn drive improved operating margins and overall profitability."Dollar Tree closed on the purchase of Family Dollar Stores July 6 after a heated takeover battle with rival deep discounter Dollar General (DG). It paid $6.8 billion in cash and 28.5 million shares of the company’s stock valued at $2.3 billion.Prior to the merger, Dollar Tree enjoyed a long-running streak of double-digit quarterly profit. The merger has the potential for synergies and productivity gains, and could enable Dollar Tree to serve a broader range of customers, tap new markets and enhance market share in existing ones while enhancing the company’s financial performance and improving its growth prospects, the company said at the time of the buy.“The draw (for investors) is the opportunity the company has to dramatically improve the earnings power of the Family Dollar segment,” Northcoast Research analyst Nicholas Mitchell told IBD.But the integration and turnaround processes present challenges, say followers. While analysts praise Dollar Tree management’s capabilities, opinions are mixed on the extent to which Dollar Tree will achieve its objectives.“I think Dollar Tree is a very successful retailer and they're very good operators,” Stifel analyst Taylor LaBarr told IBD. “But it was a big step acquiring a company that was bigger than they are, with even more employees, more distribution centers and more stores. It is a big acquisition and integration task for any situation, but they’re also trying to fix and turn around a struggling retailer. So we really like the core Dollar Tree business, but it’s going to be a tough integration.”Dollar Tree’s stock price rose 9.7% last year, though it’s been up and down so far this year. Its stock price has also soared 44% since the retailer announced its intent to buy Family Dollar on July 28, 2014.Dollar Tree operated 13,851 stores across 48 states and five Canadian provinces as of Jan. 30. Stores operate under the brands of Dollar Tree, Family Dollar, Dollar Tree Canada and Deals. It expects to have 217 of the 222 Deals stores converted to the Dollar Tree brand and five to Family Dollar brands by July. Dollar Tree converted 52 Deals stores to Dollar Tree stores in January.Dollar Tree operates fixed-price point stores, selling everything for $1 or less, while Family Dollar operates multiprice point stores, selling the majority of its products at $10 or less.Post merger, Dollar Tree faces new rivals.When it acquired Family Dollar, Dollar Tree gained more direct competition with Dollar General, convenience stores, the front end of drug stores, and to some degree giant discounters Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Target (TGT), says analyst Mitchell.“The acquisition made the business more complicated and levered up the balance sheet,” Mitchell said. “It used to be a very uncomplicated investment story that investors felt comfortable buying with the intention of holding the shares as a core position. These guys were so good at merchandising and real estate site selection that the cash flow could efficiently be reinvested in the business with expectations of earning a high return on the incremental capital.”Mitchell went on to say: “After it acquired Family Dollar, the story went from being a very clean investment story with very good unit economics and a strong competitive advantage to a story that's half the same and the other half a turnaround story. I would imagine that it has probably been a little more challenging than (management) thought it would be at the start, but they are making good progress cleaning up many of the underlying problems they inherited.”On the plus side, Dollar Tree has turned out two straight quarters of positive same-store sales for Family Dollar, which is a nice improvement, Mitchell says. It’s also cleaned up the Family Dollar stores, strengthened the end-of-the-aisle displays and improved the “in-stock” position in these stores, he says.“It’s going to take time to get the consumer back,” he added. “There’s a lot of work ahead that needs to be done. The final verdict on whether this was a smart move will be a function of execution in the next 12 to 18 months.”In the fiscal 2015 fourth quarter, which ended Jan. 30, Dollar Tree’s adjusted earnings fell 13% to $1.01 per share. Revenue surged 117% to $5.37 billion, boosted by $2.68 billion in sales from the Family Dollar segment. Family Dollar stores saw a low single-digit rise in same-store sales, driven by growth in both traffic and the average ticket.In a note to clients on Dollar Tree’s fourth-quarter results, UBS analyst Michael Lasser was upbeat about the company's prospects.“After parsing back the one-time items, (Dollar Tree) put together another solid (quarter) that puts it on pace to substantially grow its earnings over time,” he wrote.He notes that the company has now seen growth in same-store sales in each of the last seven months.“Its traffic is accelerating, and improvements are being made,” he added. “This provides a more stable base from which its (same-store sales) can accelerate.”

Loading the player... Stocks fired up, then flamed out, and then found a second up-stage Thursday, reacting to European news that ultimately created only uncertainty. The Nasdaq ended down 0.3%, after being up almost 1% and down 1.4%. The S&P 500 finished a fraction above break-even. Volume rose on both major exchanges. The IBD 50 slipped 0.4%. News gave the market an early…

Teens and tweens love shopping, and a weekly allowance stretches far at Five Below (FIVE).With its ever-rotating trendy offerings, the rapidly expanding store chain is a haven for the adolescent set. There are shelves of cell-phone accessories, toys, fashions, sports gear, candy and seasonal items -- all for just $5 and below.To the average adult, it may sound like a pubescent-laced nightmare. But there's serious money behind catering to one of the more free-spending demographics out there.Dan Binder, an analyst with Jefferies, says he’s had a buy rating on the stock since its initial public offering in July 2012.“I like the story; I like the store concept,” Binder told IBD. “Most importantly my teenage girls like it too. I will regularly offer them the opportunity to go to movies or to go to Five Below. They usually pick Five Below.”And for those who would gladly leave the shopping at Five Below to their kids, consider this: It currently has 437 outlets in 27 states and has opened 70 of those in 2015 alone."We’ve had a great year,” Chief Executive Joel Anderson said on a January 2016 conference call. The company says it will grow even faster in 2016, adding roughly 85 stores.Anderson says the company is growing using four strategies: opening new stores and new markets; smart merchandising; increased digital marketing and brand awareness; and building infrastructure and systems that scale. He says the company is now spending “2.5% to 3% of sales” on marketing."We want to grow to 2,000 or so stores in the U.S.,” he said. “This concept is pretty simple. We think about it as '1/10/100,' less than a one-year payback (on investment in a store), 10 years of consistent comparable store growth, and 100% of our stores are profitable.”Net income for the company’s third quarter, ended Oct. 31, rose a hefty 30% to $4.3 million from $3.3 million. Diluted earnings per share rose 33% to 8 cents from 6 cents in the year-earlier quarter.In the third quarter of 2015, Five Below reported a rise in net sales of $31.7 million or 23% to $169.7 million from $138 million in Q3 2014. Comparable or same-store sales for the period increased 4.8%, the company said.On Jan. 7, 2016, Five Below reported net sales for the nine-week period ended Jan. 2, including the holiday season, rose 24% to $286.1 million from $230.7 million in the comparable nine-week period of 2014. It also said that same-store sales for the nine-week period were up 4.1% year over year.And Five Below also said its outlook for the full fourth quarter, with final results out by the end of this month, calls for net sales of $323 million to $326 million and earnings per share of 75 to 76 cents for the quarter. Zacks puts earnings per share for the company’s fourth quarter at 76 cents.Analysts are smitten with the company’s rapid growth, market positioning and its ability to make its new stores pay.“The payback on new stores is the shortest I’ve ever seen in retail -- they have been paying back their investment in under a year,” Matt Nemer, analyst with Wells Fargo Securities in San Francisco, told IBD.Nemer has an outperform rating on the company’s stock. He notes that growing and opening stores at this rapid a pace could be cause for concern.“What mitigates that is a pretty simple store concept, and then they cluster the openings,” Nemer said. By doing that, the company is able to “focus on that market, and leverage its advertising and marketing.”Analyst Binder from Jefferies also notes that the company has been smart about how it’s building out its network of stores: “They’re keeping it pretty tight; they’re not trying to build in California when they’re still trying to fill out in the East.”Five Below’s share price has had an up and down ride over the past 12 months. It hit a 52-week intraday high on June 23 of 41.47 per share. But it tumbled all the way down to close at 27.50 on Nov. 17, due to worries about retailer Christmas sales. Since then, the price has been climbing -- even in a tough market -- and it’s now trading around 39 a share.Like other retailers, Five Below has also been clever about finding what it calls “wow” items. At Christmas, it sold a remote control helicopter for just $5, which drove a lot of traffic to its stores, analysts said. These items keep tweens and teens coming back to hunt for treasures that usually sell out quickly.In January 2015, CEO Anderson brought in Michael Romanko as executive vice president of merchandising. Nemer says that Romanko has improved the merchandise Five Below sells by bringing in more fitness and electronics products and other products he considers compelling.Binder says the company doesn’t really have a direct competitor, but rather has several rivals, from Walmart (WMT) to Target (TGT) for some goods, and Dick’s Sporting Goods (DKS) for sports gear.But he said Five Below is “deep value.” And unlike dollar stores such as Dollar General (DG) or Dollar Tree (DLTR), Five Below doesn't offer food or household items.“Without a doubt, merchandising to teens is their sweet spot,” he said.A year ago, Anderson said the company was focused on “outlining its digital marketing campaign with TV, email, social media and mobile” all being pieces of it.Anderson understands that his core customers, “teens and tweens,” are “living online.”But Five Below is using its online marketing to drive retail store sales. Analysts say that at its product price point of $5 and less, the company doesn’t have to worry about competition from online retailers.“Five Below’s product prices are so low it would be very difficult to make money shipping them to someone’s home,” said Nemer.Five Below’s puny prices also give the stores the ability to “do well in a strong or a weak economy” when customers have less money to spend, noted Nemer.

Stocks have been moving in line with the price of oil this year, and Wednesday was no different, as the major averages ended higher.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.5%, and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.2%. Volume in the stock market today fell 12% on the NYSE and 9% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Investors have used oil prices as a barometer for the global economy, selling when oil prices fall and then buying when crude rises. U.S. crude prices jumped more than 4% Wednesday, rising back above $38 a barrel.As might be expected, oil stocks led the gains. Chevron (CVX) paced the Dow industrials, rising more than 4%. Outside the Dow, Tesoro (TSO), a refiner, rose more than 5%.But there were pockets of success elsewhere. LGI Homes (LGIH) popped nearly 10% in huge volume after the homebuilder posted a 121% gain in Q4 profit to 75 cents a share, beating Wall Street forecasts. Sales rose 63% to $176.8 million, slightly below views.Meanwhile, biotech stocks took a hit after the government announced a test program to lower Medicare drug costs. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) plunged 5%, Amgen (AMGN) dropped nearly 3%, and Celgene (CELG) lost more than 1%.Dollar General (DG), El Pollo Loco (LOCO) and Children's Place (PLCE) are due to report quarterly results Thursday.Economic data scheduled for Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended March 5 and the Treasury budget for February. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank holds a policy meeting Thursday.Image provided by Shutterstock.

What a difference a week can make. Now with the stock market notching three straight up-days and back in a confirmed uptrend, the number of stocks making today's Weekly Review list has increased. It's still well shy of normal levels, but is now filling up two pages for the first time in weeks. During a healthy market, 120 companies make…

Today's IBD 50 list includes four highly-rated retailers that have shown strength lately, while giants like Wal-Mart (WMT) have been losing ground.The world's largest retailer cut its full-year forecast Thursday and now sees sales coming in about flat, dashing hopes that recent initiatives would spark faster growth.Meanwhile, consumers continue to watch their budgets closely, and that's helping discount clothiers Ross Stores (ROST), Five Below (FIVE) and deep discounter Dollar General (DG) outperform the market.At the high end of the retail spectrum, shares of luxury clothing and accessories brand Michael Kors (KORS) popped 24% on Feb. 2 after it reported quarterly earnings and sales growth that easily beat Wall Street estimates.The chain is well positioned to weather the current market uncertainty and rising competition from online retailers such as Amazon.com (AMZN), Morningstar and others say."They're one of the best" traditional brick-and-mortar retailers, Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar told IBD recently, referring to Ross.Ross doesn't tout luxury brands or even have an online shop. But it's outperformed rivals in part by purchasing "packaway" inventory -- goods bought at a low price and packed away for months or years for later sale, no matter what the current fashions are.Shares have formed a deep first-stage base with a 56.78 buy point. Ross, which which will report fourth-quarter results on March 1, closed down 0.2% Friday.Teen apparel discount chain Five Below is expected to report robust holiday sales when it announces Q4 earnings next month. On Jan. 7, the company raised its guidance for the nine-week period ended Jan. 2.CEO Joel Anderson said at the time in a written statement that, "given our holiday performance, we are raising our net sales outlook for the fourth quarter to a range of $323 million to $326 million and are narrowing our earnings per share guidance range to 75 cents to 76 cents."That's up from Five Below's earlier outlook for EPS of 74-76 cents on $318 million-$323 million in revenue. Shares lost 0.2% Friday.Deep discount general merchandise retailer Dollar General has seen earnings and revenue growth fall off in recent quarters, though the company continues to show remarkable stability.That led Morgan Stanley to raise its rating on Dollar General on Feb. 16 from equal-weight to overweight.Its shares have a 93 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 93% of all stocks in recent quarters on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. Dollar General slipped 0.8% Friday.The outlier in the group, Michael Kors, is a leader in the luxury clothing, accessories and footwear category.In its Feb. 2 fiscal Q3 earnings announcement, Kors reported a 7.4% rise in EPS to $1.59 on a 6.2% increase in revenue to $1.397 billion. Both were an upside surprise to Wall Street.The company forecasts fiscal 2016 sales of $4.65 billion, easily topping analyst consensus for $4.42 billion.Chairman and CEO John Idol said in the earnings statement, "As we look ahead, we are excited about our upcoming Spring collections that embody design innovation and underscore Michael Kors fashion leadership." Shares fell 1%.

Stock indexes in the U.S. were mixed in early afternoon trade Friday as volume picked up from the previous session.The Nasdaq reversed from early losses to ante up a 0.4% gain. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were down 0.1% and 0.3%, respectively. Volume was running higher in the stock market today, which is normal on an options expirations day.Blue chips were mostly down. American Express (AXP) posted the best price gain in the Dow, up 1% as it headed toward a fifth up day in a row. Bloomberg News reported this week that the company plans to cut costs by $1 billion over the next two years.In the IBD 50, a list of the best stocks in fundamentals and technicals, the discount stores were hesitating. Ross Stores (ROST) and Dollar General (DG) each fell about 1% in above-average volume. Five Below (FIVE) was down moderately in slow trade.The discount stores are somewhat defensive. Aggressive growth investors would like to see those kind of retail stocks leave the computer-generated IBD 50 in favor of more aggressive plays. However, it isn't clear whether conservative stocks are ready to step aside for growth stocks.Many growth stocks are badly damaged. For example, analysts expect Under Armour (UA) to crank up earnings growth 25% this year and 28% next year. That would be an improvement over 2015's 11% earnings growth and a return to the five-year growth rate of 26%.However, Under Armour remains under its 200-day line and is 23% off its high.

Stocks were lower at midday Thursday as investors weighed mixed economic data and another jump in oil prices.The Nasdaq was down 0.6%, the S&P 500 fell 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.2%. Volume was running lower across the board amid the stock market's decline.Oil producers were among the day's worst performers even though crude prices continued to rebound, jumping more than 2% to over $33 a barrel.Marathon Oil (MRO) was down 7% following its Q4 earnings report. The company lost 48 cents a share during the period as revenue dropped 41% to $1.5 billion as oil prices plunged. The company halved its capital spending budget for this year compared with 2015 and said it plans to cut productionNewfield Exploration (NFX) dropped 8% while Murphy Oil (MUR) lost 7%.Wal-Mart (WMT) led the Dow lower, sinking almost 5%. The retail giant's Q4 earnings decline narrowly beat Wall Street estimates, but fourth-quarter revenue and full-year revenue guidance trailed analysts' forecast.Dollar General (DG), another discount retailer, dropped nearly 3% and sliced through its 200-day moving average. The stock is working on a cup-with-handle base with a 76.85 buy point.IBD 50 stocks were mixed. Universal Display (OLED) led on the upside, rising nearly 5% in heavy volume.  The maker of electronics products such as light-emitting diodes for flat panel displays is trying to recover from a failed breakout over a 55.93 buy point.The company will release Q4 results Feb. 25 after the close. Profit for the period is expected to jump 82% to 51 cents a share on a 27% increase in sales to $71.5 million.In economic news, initial claims for jobless claims benefits declined last week, but the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's index of manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region continued to show contraction and the Conference Board's index of leading indicators slipped 0.2% in January,  in line with expectations.

Today's IBD 50 list, which pinpoints top-performing growth stocks, includes five that made the elite list, fell off and then climbed back aboard.They are Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), Michael Kors (KORS), Five Below (FIVE), Sturm Ruger (RGR) and Smith & Wesson (SWHC).Here's a look at what's happened at these top performers that's put them back on the IBD 50.Natural and organic foods grocer Sprouts Farmers Market continues to rise on strong earnings growth while rivals Whole Foods Market (WFM) and The Fresh Market (TFM) saw lackluster growth last year amid rising competition from supermarket giant Kroger (KR), Amazon (AMZN) and others.On Feb. 25, Sprouts reported a 50% surge in Q4 earnings  and a 27% pop in revenue to $930.3 million. Both figures crushed analyst estimates.Meanwhile, reports that Kroger is looking to buy The Fresh Market have added to expectations of industry consolidation.Sprouts, which boasts a 98 IBD Composite Rating out of a best-possible 99, fell 1.6% Friday.The trendy Hong Kong-based maker of fashion clothes, footwear and accessories took the U.S. and Europe by storm a few years ago. Its stock price soared 405% from 20 at its initial public offering in December 2011 to an all-time high of 101.04 on Feb. 28, 2014, before it consolidated amid execution problems.In February, Kors had its biggest up week in four years on an earnings report that surprised Wall Street analysts.On Feb. 2, its stock shot up 24% and continued rising. Shares ended essentially flat Friday.Deep discount retailers such as Five Below, which sells preteen and teen products for $5 or less, along with Dollar Tree (DLTR), Dollar General (DG) and bulk discounter Big Lots (BIG), saw sales surge during and after the Great Recession, when people were pinching pennies.The trend among consumers to buy at discounts has lingered even as the recession has receded. On Wednesday, Five Below opened its first store in Miami, expanding its store count in the state to 17, with plans to open over 100 more in Florida.Five Below rose 2.8% to 38.77.The nation's largest firearms maker, Smith & Wesson, sees dramatic swings. The Aurora, Colo., movie theater shooting in July 2012 and the Sandy Hook school shooting in December 2012 sent sales, profit and the stock soaring as fears of tougher laws sparked a rush to buy ahead of any legislative action.But demand waned as attempts in Congress to pass new gun limits failed, sending Smith & Wesson's stock tumbling.The mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., on Dec. 2 revived the gun debate and helped fiscal Q3 results top views late Thursday.Its stock cleared a cup-with-handle base on Friday, touching an all-time high at 27.99 before closing at 27.06, up 6.5% for the day.No. 2 U.S. firearms maker Sturm Ruger reported Q4 results last month that handily beat Wall Street forecasts.On a conference call with analysts, CEO Michael Fifer predicted a ramp-up in demand if Democrats take the White House and Senate, as the next president could get several opportunities to appoint new Supreme Court justices.Sturm Ruger shares closed up 5%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Dollar Tree (DLTR) CEO Bob Sasser called it a "virtual certainty" that the Federal Trade Commission will approve its takeover bid for Family Dollar Stores (FDO).In a Jan. 9 letter to Family Dollar shareholders, Sasser also warned that his company isn't willing to agree to any further delays on a vote by Family Dollar to approve the offer and that it could walk away from the deal."After two delays, we have been more than reasonable but have reached the end of our patience," he wrote.At a Dec. 23 meeting that was scheduled for a vote on the bid, Family Dollar shareholders voted instead to adjourn and move the meeting to Jan. 22, saying that there weren't enough votes to OK the offer. The Dec. 23 meeting had already been delayed from Dec. 11.Shares were down 0.8% on the stock market today. Family Dollar fell 1.6%. Dollar General (DG), which has made a competing bid for Family Dollar, slid 1.3%.Dollar Tree said Monday that it expects to reach a preliminary agreement with the FTC's staff on the list of some 300 stores to be divested by the end of January.The chain also expects to line up financing in February for its $74.50-per-share, $8.5 billion offer and said that the money should enable the merger to close as soon as March.The FTC is reviewing the Dollar Tree offer as well as Dollar General's $80-per-share, $9 billion bid to determine whether either plan or both would be anti-competitive.Dollar Tree claimed that Dollar General proposal has a far greater number of stores than Dollar Tree, which raises concerns for the FTC."Dollar Tree remains convinced that the FTC will require divestitures far in excess of Dollar General's wholly inadequate store divestiture commitment," the company said in the update.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar .

Looking to 2015, a trio of analysts from Sterne Agee on Monday singled out deep discounter Dollar General (DG) and vitamin and nutritional supplements retailer GNC Holdings (GNC) as their "highest conviction ideas."

Led by broadlines/health and wellness retail analyst Charles Grom, the analysts chose Dollar General as their top pick. The reasons: an improving backdrop for lower income consumers and "consolidation optionality" from a likely acquisition of Family Dollar Stores (FDO), which is pending shareholder approval.
That deal "should create both earnings accretion and pricing rationalization," the analysts noted in Monday's report.
They said they believe that Dollar General will end up with Family Dollar. But even if it doesn't, Dollar General has a "solid business model" with "strong development prospects."
GNC was touted for its new leadership, broadening customer base on the heels of new-product rollouts and easier same-store sales comparisons to the weather-challenged previous year.

In August, amid slowing sales and earnings growth, the Pittsburgh-based GNC hired Michael Archbold to replace Joseph Fortunato as CEO. Archbold had been CEO of women's apparel retailer The Talbots and previously served as president of Vitamin Shoppe (VSI).

Sterne Agee noted that strategic options "potentially on the table" for GNC include the acquisition of Vitamin Shoppe, slower store growth or store closings, refranchising and increased share buybacks.

Dollar General is highly rated by IBD, with a Composite Rating of 96 out of a possible 99, based on metrics such as stock and earnings strength. GNC has a Composite Rating of 81.Looking to 2015, a trio of analysts from Sterne Agee on Monday singled out deep discounter Dollar General (DG) and vitamin and nutritional supplements retailer GNC Holdings (GNC) as their "highest conviction ideas."Led by broadlines/health and wellness retail analyst Charles Grom, the analysts chose Dollar General as their top pick. Dollar Tree (DLTR) stock sold off Tuesday on weaker-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and current-year guidance, but shares rebounded off their 50-day moving average to turn higher.Dollar Tree earnings fell 13% to $1.01 per share, falling short of views for $1.07 a share. Revenue shot up 117% to $5.37 billion, thanks to the company's Family Dollar takeover, but still missed estimates for $5.41 billion.Same-store sales at Dollar Tree stores grew 1.7% on a constant currency basis vs. 5.6% comp growth in Q4 of last year. Sales at Dollar Tree stores open for at least a year rose 1.3% once adjusted for the impact of Canadian currency fluctuations, the company said.Dollar Tree expects diluted per-share earnings of 75-83 cents in Q1, in line with consensus for 79 cents. The midpoint of its revenue guidance for $5.05 billion-$5.12 billion falls slightly below analyst estimates for $5.1 billion.For the year, the company guided for $3.35-$3.65 a share in earnings, below forecasts for $3.76 a share. The midpoint of targeted revenue of $20.76 billion-$21.11 billion is a hair above current estimates for $20.93 billion.Soon after the open, Dollar Tree stock tumbled to 77.77, just below its 50-day moving average, but it then rallied strongly and closed up 2.2%. The stock had briefly undercut an 80.14 buy point.Dollar General broke out of a cup-with-handle base in early January at that 80.14 buy point, but the attempt quickly failed, and shares have been up and down since then. Shares hit an eight-month closing high on Friday. Another buy point at 82.86  is available on a longer-term consolidation going back to the all-time high set in March 2015.Rival Dollar General (DG) shares rose 1.75%.Image provided by Shutterstock.RELATED:What Correction? Dollar Tree Breaks Out.

The IBD 50 is coming out of its worst-ever correction, a temblor that's changed the composition of the list.To its February low, the IBD 50 declined more than 26% from a peak in July 2015. The move marks the largest decline in the index since its inception in 2011. (That's excluding its predecessor, the IBD 100.)After a drop of such magnitude, you can expect significant changes in the composition of the list. The high-growth companies typically found in the list thinned out, while some slower-growth stocks emerged.Equity Lifestyle Properties (ELS) exemplifies the new crop. The real estate investment trust increased earnings 5% to 12% the past four quarters. Sales rose 5% to 7% over those periods. The stock itself is in fine shape, trending upward and near highs.It is one of several REITs in the IBD 50, as companies that reward shareholders with high dividends gained the favor of Wall Street.Dollar General (DG), the deep-discount retailer, typically has profit and sales growth in the teens or lower. Prestige Brands (PBH) -- which makes cleaning products and over-the-counter medications -- posted an EPS gain of 10% in Q4 and sales only 1% higher. Both stocks are forming bases.That's not to say the IBD 50 is no longer a growth screen. The average earnings-per-share increase for the 50 companies in the most recent report was a solid 37%. The average EPS estimate for the next report is nearly 26%.Indeed, some faces on the IBD 50 are experiencing a resurgence in growth.For instance, Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) on Thursday beat profit expectations as EPS soared 50%, with its 2016 forecast above estimates. Earnings rose 9%, 10% and 17% in the previous quarters, respectively, so the organic-groceries chain is in a rapid acceleration.A.O. Smith (AOS), which is recovering from a steep correction, has been bouncing back since it reported a 41% rise in earnings Jan. 29. The maker of high-efficiency water heaters is also enjoying accelerating profits, but sales growth has slowed.Vantiv (VNTV) has generated a more moderate acceleration, with EPS rising 15%, 19%, 20% and 23% over the respective four latest quarters. The payment-processing company is benefiting from the shift to cards with embedded chips for higher security, as today's IBD Stock Analysis explains on Page B10.For the week, the IBD 50 rose 0.5%, lagging the Nasdaq's 1.9% gain and the S&P 500's 1.6% advance.

Despite Dollar Tree's criticism of Dollar General's unsolicited bid for Family Dollar, shares of Dollar General got a little lift in the stock market Friday.

Dollar Tree (DLTR)initiated the exchange, saying that the Federal Trade Commission could require Dollar General (DG) to divest "far in excess" of the 1,500 locations Dollar General initially said it was willing to shed.

A "relatively small number" of divestitures is required under the Dollar Tree (DLTR) merger with Family Dollar, Dollar Tree said in a statement. Dollar Tree believes it won't have to sell more than 500 of its 5,300 store locations to get regulatory approval.
Dollar Tree's proposal to acquire Family Dollar has been accepted by the Family Dollar board and is heading for a Family Dollar shareholder vote Dec. 23.

In response to Dollar Tree's comments, Dollar General said it "is actively engaged in discussions" with the FTC "regarding the extent of potential divestitures that would be required in connection with an acquisition of Family Dollar and has been making good progress."
Dollar General shares rose 0.8% by midafternoon trading in the stock market today, Friday, while Dollar Tree fell 1.2% and Family Dollar was flat.
But Dollar Tree's dis didn't stop there.

"While roughly 150 Family Dollar (FDO) stores adjust prices due at least in part to the presence of Dollar Tree, about 5,400 Family Dollar stores adjust prices due at least in part to the presence of Dollar General," Dollar Tree said, adding that Dollar General may have difficulty finding and reaching agreements with buyers for the thousands of stores it may need to sell.

Dollar Tree also said that its business model complements Family Dollar's, while Dollar General's is too similar to the takeover target. The latter two companies sell branded consumable products at multiple price points up to $20 or more, while Dollar Tree sells everything for $1 or less.
Dollar General, which has about 11,500 store locations nationwide, fired back that "Walmart, not Family Dollar, is the primary driver regarding Dollar General's strategic pricing decisions.

"There is no reason to believe that the FTC would take into account only Family Dollar's documents and data or afford them greater significance than Dollar General's own evidence," Dollar General said, adding that it has provided regulators with "tens of thousands of documents" supporting its "broad view of competition."

Dollar General expects to provide an update on its $9.1 billion offer in time for Family Dollar shareholders to review such information prior to the Family Dollar shareholders' Dec. 23 meeting to vote on the Dollar Tree-Family Dollar merger.
The $8.5 billion Dollar Tree-Family Dollar merger, which would operate a total of 13,400 stores, is expected to close in February 2015.
The Retail-Discount & Variety group is ranked No. 17 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.
Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.

Dollar General's (DG) third-quarter results missed analyst expectations Thursday, but the company is still pursuing Family Dollar (FDO), even though the discounter has already agreed to a deal with Dollar Tree (DLTR).

Dollar General's Q3 earnings jumped 10% to 79 cents per share. That fell short of the 80 cents analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Sales rose 7.8% to $4.72 billion, also under views for $4.76 billion. Same-store sales rose 2.8%.
Dollar General noted strong sales in its home and apparel categories and said it expanded market share in consumables.
Shares fell 0.4% to 66.45 in pre-market trading in the stock market today, Thursday.

"We are seeing a significant step up as we start the holiday season, and we expect to achieve same-store sales growth of approximately 5% for the fourth quarter," CEO Rick Dreiling said in the earnings release.
The company narrowed full-year EPS to $3.45 to $3.55, the middle of its prior outlook. Analysts are expecting $3.53.

"Finally, we remain committed to acquiring Family Dollar," Dreiling said. "We expect to provide an update on our offer in time for Family Dollar shareholders to review such information prior to the Family Dollar shareholders' meeting scheduled for Dec. 23, 2014."

But Dollar Tree has already signed an $8.5 billion deal to buy Family Dollar. Family Dollar rejected Dollar General's bid on antitrust issues. Reports surfaced last month that Dollar General may have to divest 4,000 stores, more than double the 1,500 outlets it originally stated as part of its offer.
The Retail-Discount and Variety group is ranked No. 18 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.

Dollar Tree (DLTR) stock fell 8.7% Tuesday after the variety-store discounter missed sales views in the second quarter, its first with Family Dollar Stores under its helm.
Dollar Tree reported $3.01 billion in net sales in the quarter, up 48.3% from the prior year. Family Dollar, which Dollar Tree acquired on July 6, contributed $811.6 million.

Analysts expected $3.04 billion in revenue, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters. Dollar Tree's full-year revenue forecast of $15.30-$15.52 billion also was below analysts' views for $15.57 billion.
Dollar Tree didn't provide earnings forecasts due to integration and divestiture issues related to the Family Dollar acquisition.
That omission "adds to the uncertainty of the story, suggesting (Family Dollar) could continue to weigh on profitability," noted Wells Fargo analyst Matt Nemer in a client note.

Acquisition-related costs caused a net loss of 46 cents per share. Excluding those costs, per-share earnings fell 59% over last year to 25 cents. But adjusted to exclude acquisition-related costs and share changes, the Dollar Tree segment earned 67 cents per share. Analysts recently lowered their Q2 forecast from 67 cents to 62 cents, according to Thomson Reuters.
Gross margin fell to 28.4% vs. 34.2% in the prior year, due largely to factors related to Family Dollar, including its lower-margin product mix.

But CEO Bob Sasser was upbeat. "We are now an organization with annual sales exceeding $19 billion, more than 13,800 stores across North America and a network of more than 145,000 associates," he said in the Q2 release.
He said the company, now larger than chief rival Dollar General (DG), expects $300 million in annual synergies by the end of the third year's post-acquisition.

Same-store sales in the Dollar Tree segment rose a lower-than-expected 2.7% in the quarter, driven by gains in customer count and average ticket. They were up against a tough comparison from the prior year's same quarter, when same-store sales grew 4.5%.

Dollar General also fell short of revenue views when it reported Q2 results last week, though per-share earnings beat by a penny, rising 14% to 95 cents. Both Dollar Tree and Dollar General compete with big-box discounter Wal-Mart (WMT), which posted weaker-than-expected profit last month and cut its outlook for the full year.

Dollar General fell 3.6% Tuesday. Big Lots' (BIG) first-quarter earnings beat analyst estimates, but the discounter issued weak second-quarter guidance.
On Friday Big Lots said Q1 EPS rose 20% to 60 cents, a penny above the 59 cents that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Sales were flat at $1.28 billion.
Before the open, shares were pushing up slightly in the stock market today.
Same-store sales were up 1.6%, in line with the 1% to 2% jump Big Lots was expecting.

"I'm pleased with our first-quarter sales results. After a difficult start to the quarter and harsh weather conditions in February, sales trends improved in March and April," said CEO David Campisi. "Our comps for Q1 were solidly in line with our guidance and increased for a fifth consecutive quarter."
For the current quarter, Big Lots sees EPS of 31 cents to 35 cents and same-store sales increasing 2% to 3%. Analysts are expecting earnings of 37 cents per share.
Big Lots raised the low end of its full-year EPS outlook to a range of $2.80 to $2.90, up from $2.75 to $2.90. Analysts forecast $2.87.
On Thursday, rival Dollar General (DG) named Todd Vasos as its new CEO, effective June 3.
The Retail-Discount & Variety group is ranked No. 167 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.

Earnings season is waning just as holiday gifting season is winding up. And as Black Friday orders start shipping out, today's IBD 50 roundup features four companies that are outperforming the market and plan to report quarterly figures this week. Ambarella (AMBA), which provides processing chips to GoPro (GPRO) and other gadget companies, is expected to report Q3 per-share earnings…
Dollar Tree (DLTR) reported the best same-store sales growth since 2011 on Thursday, sending shares rising.

The discounter's Q3 jumped 19% to 69 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 64 cents. Sales climbed 11% to $2.09 billion, above views for $2.06 billion. Same-store sales rose 5.9%, topping estimates of 4% from Consensus Matrix, according to Reuters.
Shares jumped 6% to 66.45 in the the stock market today.
Dollar Tree sees full year sales of $8.52 billion to $8.58 billion, up from an earlier outlook of $8.44 billion to $8.55 billion. Analysts are expecting $8.57 billion.

The company signed a $8.5 billion deal to buy Family Dollar (FDO), but Dollar General (DG) put in its own $9.1 billion bid. Family Dollar rejected the Dollar General bid on antitrust issues, and the New York Post reported Wednesday that Dollar General may have to divest 4,000 stores, more than double the 1,500 outlets it originally stated as part of its offer.
Family Dollar shares dipped 0.3% to 78.23. Dollar General shares rose 1% to 66.78.
Discounters are facing stiff competition from Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT).

Last week Wal-Mart reported a 0.5% rise in U.S. same-store sales, the first increase in seven quarters. On Wednesday, Target reported a 1.2% jump in U.S. comps as overall sales rose 3%, beating analyst estimates.
The Retail-Discount & Variety group is ranked No. 11 out of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.
Dollar Tree is highly ranked with a 97 out of a possible 99 Composite Rating. IBD's Composite Rating measures stocks in five areas, with extra weight on earnings and stock price strength.

Stocks trimmed their losses in early afternoon trading, ahead of the minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's Oct. 29 meeting.The Nasdaq shed 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average remained 0.1% lower. Volume was tracking higher in the stock market today, compared with the same time Tuesday.On the economic front, housing starts eased more than expected in October, although building permits topped forecasts. The Fed minutes release is slated for 2 p.m. ET.Specialty retailers advanced, led by a 5% big-volume jump in PetSmart (PETM), which hit its highest level in more than a year. The pet supplies retailer late Tuesday reported Q3 results that beat views.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 3% in average trade and is now 6% above a 121.53 cup-with-handle buy point.Dollar General (DG) gapped down and fell 3% in heavy volume. It's now 3% below a 65.20 cup-with-handle buy point that it cleared last week. The discount chain may have to divest about 4,000 stores in order to gain approval from the Federal Trade Commission for its takeover offer for Family Dollar Stores (FDO), according to the New York Post.On the upside,Zillow (Z) vaulted 5% in fast trade, on track to extend its gains for a fourth straight session. The stock reclaimed its 10-week moving average for the first time since early September. Hedge fund Caledonia said at a London conference that the online real estate play could reach an enterprise value of $50 billion.Lowe's (LOW) gapped up and soared 7% to a new high after reporting Q3 earnings that rose 26% to 59 cents a share, a penny over views. Sales climbed 6% to $13.7 billion, also beating. The building products retailer also lifted its full-year sales and same-store sales forecasts.Follow Nancy Gondo on Twitter: @IBD_NGondo.
Low-priced teen and pre-teen retailer Five Below (FIVE) is hitching a ride on the recent iPhone 6 launch.

Five Below began stocking iPhone 6-compatible cases less than two weeks after Apple (AAPL) launched the new models and at "a fraction of the price" of other retailers, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Matt Nemer said in a report Monday.
Now the company is in the midst of overhauling its popular consumer electronics department to better display mobile phone accessories such as iPhone cases, Nemer said.
Nemer said the new displays should "greatly improve the shopping experience" and could drive same-store sales up by as much as 20 basis points.
"We see the new iPhone launch as a catalyst for the entire electronics department as parents hand down their older generation phones, spurring demand for accessories," Nemer said.

In the new displays, accessories for various mobile phones such as the iPhone 4/5 and Samsung Galaxy line are grouped separately in round, stand-alone fixtures to make it easier for customers to shop by platform and device.
That's a change from horizontal displays of co-mingled products. Though only in select stores now, Nemer expects the new displays to be rolled out quickly and chain-wide.
Nemer noted that Five Below's electronics accessories section "appears to be the most heavily trafficked section of the store."
Nemer says Five Below's "speed to market" in coming out with new iPhone 6 cases is similar to fast-fashion retailers "who offer low-price, on-trend merchandise."
"Five Below is in an elite class of high growth retailers, with a differentiated value-oriented concept," he wrote.

Five Below sells a variety of low-priced merchandise targeted to teens and pre-teens. The company is in IBD's Retail-Discount and Variety industry group, which is ranked No. 14 in performance of 197 groups tracked.
The company is highly rated by IBD with a Composite Rating of 94 out of a possible 99.

Two other highly rated stocks in the group are Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Dollar General (DG), with Composite Ratings of 96 and 95, respectively.Low-priced teen and pre-teen retailer Five Below (FIVE) is hitching a ride on the recent iPhone 6 launch.Five Below began stocking iPhone 6-compatible cases less than two weeks after Apple (AAPL) launched the new models and at "a fraction of the price" of other retailers, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Matt Nemer said in a report Monday.Now the company is in the midst of overhauling its popular consumer electronics department to better display mobile phone accessories such as iPhone cases, Nemer said.Nemer said the new displays should "greatly improve the shopping experience" and could drive same-store sales up by as much as 20 basis points."We see the new iPhone launch as a catalyst for the entire electronics department as parents hand down their older generation phones, spurring demand for accessories," Nemer said.In the new displays, accessories for various mobile phones such as the iPhone 4/5 and Samsung Galaxy line are grouped separately in round, stand-alone fixtures to make it easier for customers to shop by platform and device.That's a change from horizontal displays of co-mingled products. Stock futures deepened their early losses ahead of Tuesday's open after a weaker-than-expected September durable goods report. Dow futures traded down 56 points and were falling. S&P 500 futures slipped 7.7 points.
Nasdaq futures, which had pared losses over the past hour, reversed and fell 11 points below fair market value.
The stock market today faces a busy session. The Federal Open Market Committee swings into its two-day meeting in Washington, with a policy announcement due out Wednesday afternoon.
A great many investors will be tuned to the aftermarket session, when Apple (AAPL) is scheduled to report fiscal Q4 results.

Economic news opened with durable goods orders, which slipped 1.2% in September, according to the Commerce Department. That was a bit worse than projections for a 1% decline. The department also revised August's decline down to 3% from 2.3%. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.4%, down from August's flat performance and deeper than the projected 0.1% slip.

Case-Shiller reports its 20-City Composite Home Price Index for August at 9 a.m. ET. Researcher Markit releases its preliminary purchasing managers index estimate for U.S. services at 9:45 a.m. The Conference Board plans to report its October Consumer Confidence index at 10 a.m.
Earnings action was thick and heavy rolling toward Tuesday's open.

Beleaguered German chip equipment maker Aixtron (AIXG) spiked 11%. U.K.-based big oil play BP (BP) added almost 2%. Big pharma names Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) rolled up 2% gains after reporting better-than-expected Q3 results.

On the downside, frac sand quarrier Hi-Crush Partners (HCLP) imploded 26% after missing earnings forecasts and suspending its cash distribution. Rent-A-Center (RCII) posted a 20% premarket meltdown — it missed Q3 revenue expectations and lowered its Q4 and full-year earnings guidance. Ford (F) slipped 3%. United Parcel Service (UPS) dimmed 3%.

Alibaba (BABA) rumbled up 10% before the bell, launching a premarket rally among many China-based stocks. The China-based diversified Internet play reported a 27% EPS gain and a 32% rise in revenue in its fiscal Q2 — both easily topped consensus forecasts. Mobile revenue rose 183%. Cloud computing and Internet infrastructure revenues rose 128%.

The company also announced that the Securities and Exchange Commission gave notice that it concluded its inquiry and no enforcement action would be recommended. Alibaba shares ended Monday about 6% below their 200-day moving average. The stock has climbed 33% from a late-September low, leaving it still 36% below its Nov. 2014 high and 12% above its Sept. 2014 IPO price.
Yahoo (YHOO) swept ahead 6% early Tuesday as investors accounted for the increased value of Yahoo's 15% stake in Alibaba. Yahoo remains deep in an 11-month consolidation.
Other China-based Internet plays caught some of Alibaba's premarket heat. JD.com (JD) and 500.com (WBAI) popped 5% each. Jumei International (JMEI) and Vipshop (VIPS) jumped up 3% apiece.

Chip developer Marvell Technology (MRVL) tanked 18% after announcing late Monday that PricewaterhouseCoopers had resigned as the company's accounting firm. Marvell in September announced an internal investigation into whether some revenue was recognized earlier than it should have been. Marvell shares have been in a steep correction since February.

Cummins (CMI) dived 9% after missing expectations on both its earnings and revenue lines in Q3. Management lowered its full-year revenue outlook to flat to down 2% vs. prior guidance for a 2% to 4% gain. The Columbus, Ind.-based diesel engine maker also announced it would lay off up to 2,000 workers. Shares have been in a deepening decline since June 2014.
Among leaders, IBD 50 stocks were relatively quiet, with more than 80% of the group unmoved in premarket trade.

Among gainers, Cirrus Logic (CRUS) rose 2% after toppling 13% in heavy trade on Monday. No stock posted a decline of more than 0.3%.Stock futures deepened their early losses ahead of Tuesday's open after a weaker-than-expected September durable goods report.
