The stock market closed higher Thursday, although indexes pared gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq, but winners barely edged out losers on the NYSE.
Computer, trucking and financials ranked among the day's top performing sectors. Retail, metals and energy stocks lagged.
A weak forecast sent a chill through homebuilding stocks in the stock market today.

Meritage Homes (MTH) cut its forecast for 2015 earnings, citing rising labor costs, delays in closings and slower-than-expected business in the company's newer markets in the Southeast. The stock fell 9% in heavy trading, to the lowest level since early February.

"There are shortages of skilled labor in many markets as subcontractors struggle to catch up with the increased demand of a continued recovery in homebuilding," said Chairman and CEO Steven J. Hilton. Competition for labor is raising costs and lengthening construction times, his statement added. Bad weather in parts of Texas and Colorado further hurt the company.
The homebuilders' industry group, which has been a market leader, was one of the worst 20 groups Thursday out of 197 that IBD tracks.

One of the day's biggest losers was Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which plunged 16% after the yoga-styled apparel chain guided Q3 and full-year earnings below expectations. Shares fell to the lowest level since December.
Google (GOOGL) rose 1% and shares continued to rise from support at the 50-day moving average. But volume in Google was light.
After the close, shares of action sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) slid after the company announced quarterly results. The stock closed regular trading near a 52-week low.

Stocks were down but well off morning lows going into the noon hour Tuesday as Greece and a weak factory orders report weighed.
The major indexes were all off 0.2%. Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges in the stock market today.
The euro was up sharply as Greece submitted a proposal to break a stalemate with European leaders over its debt. European leaders met overnight Monday to fashion their own proposal.
The dollar dropped against other major currencies after April factory orders fell 0.4% vs. the consensus of a 0.1% drop. Treasuries also fell sharply for the second day.

Ambarella (AMBA) fell nearly 3%, retracing most of Monday's gain. The stock has received multiple boosts in price targets from analysts, who cite improved guidance from Ambarella customer GoPro (GRPO). Analysts are expecting earnings of 59 cents a share, a 136% increase from a year earlier, when Ambarella reports Q1 results after the close.
Delta Airlines (DAL) fell 3%. It lowered its Q2 unit revenue outlook after reporting May capacity grew faster than traffic.
Dollar General (DG) gained nearly 4% after it reported earnings that beat expectations.

IBD 50 name Horizon Pharma (HZNP) rose nearly 3% in roughly average trade. Leerink Swann initiated covered with an outperform rating and a 37 price target. It trades just above a 32.25 buy point from a flat base.Stocks were down but well off morning lows going into the noon hour Tuesday as Greece and a weak factory orders report weighed.The major indexes were all off 0.2%. Dollar General's  (DG) first-quarter earnings topped Wall Street estimates as traffic and customer spending rose. On Tuesday, the deep discounter said Q1 earnings jumped 17% to 84 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 81 cents per share. Sales climbed 8.8% to $4.92 billion, but fell short of views for $4.94 billion. Shares rose 3.26% to…
Dollar Tree (DLTR) gave weak second-quarter earnings guidance after its Q1 results missed Wall Street estimates and expanded store divestment plans to help clinch its Family Dollar acquisition.
The deep-discount retailer also expects its acquisition of Family Dollar (FDO) to close in early July. In April, the company said it expected the deal to close in May.

During a conference call, the company said it would divest 330 Family Dollar stores to get Federal Trade Commission approval for the merger. Earlier it had predicted that it would need to divest no more than 300 stores. Family Dollar has over 8,200 stores in 46 states.
Shares were up 2.5% on the stock market today after falling initially on the Q1 report.

Earnings rose 6% last quarter to 71 cents per share, but fell short of the 75 cents that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting. Sales climbed 8.8% to $2.18 billion, under views for $2.2 billion.

Adjusted for the impact of Canadian currency fluctuations, same-store sales rose 3.1%. Gross profit increased 7.5% to $748.9 million, but gross margin decreased by 40 basis points to 34.4% on increased freight costs, and issues with an accounting method change at its Canadian operations.
Dollar Tree sees Q2 EPS of 63 to 68 cents, below the 70 cents that analysts expect. The company sees Q2 sales of $2.17 billion to $2.23 billion. Analysts expect $2.2 billion.

For the year, Dollar Tree narrowed its EPS outlook to $3.32 to $3.47 from a prior guidance of $3.30 to $3.50. Analysts forecast $3.49. Dollar Tree narrowed its full-year sales outlook to $9.24 billion to $9.42 billion from $9.21 billion to $9.45 billion. Analysts expect $9.41 billion.
Dollar General (DG) earnings are on tap for June 2. Analysts expect a 14% jump in EPS to 82 cents and a 9.3% jump in sales to $4.9 billion.

Big Lots (BIG) shares fell Friday after the discounter issued soft full-year earnings guidance and reported second-quarter revenue that missed expectations.
The Columbus, Ohio-based company reported flat Q2 earnings of 31 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 30 cents.
Sales from continuing operations rose 1.2% to $1.19 billion, under analyst estimates for $1.2 billion. Same-store sales rose 1.7%, slightly below the midpoint of Big Lots' guidance of a 1%-3% gain.
Shares fell 2% to 46.28 on the stock market today.
Big Lots sees full-year EPS of $2.40-$2.50, with the midpoint of $2.45 slightly under analyst views for $2.48.
On Thursday, the company also announced a $125 million share repurchase program.
Elsewhere in the deep-discount sector, Dollar General (DG) reported Q2 earnings Thursday that matched estimates and sales that also missed views.
The Retail-Discount & Variety group is ranked No. 17 out of the 197 industry groups that IBD tracks.

Entering the Foot Locker store in Times Square on Halloween morning, you knew you were in Nike country. Front and center, Nike's newest basketball shoe, the LeBron 12 HRT of a Lion, which hit stores the day before, was displayed under glass like a work of fine art. The shoe's debut coincided with LeBron James' first NBA regular-season game playing…

Like shoppers elbowing for deals at a clearance rack, America's three major dollar stores are focusing their sights on one another. And the situation is fiercer than a Black Friday sale at midnight. The outright winner remains to be seen, but dollar stores continue to rake in the dollars, regardless of the slothy economic recovery. Dollar General (DG), which has…

As threatened, Dollar General (DG) turned its raised offer to buy Family Dollar Stores (FDO) into a hostile offer. No. 1 deep discount variety retailer Dollar General filed papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its tender offer for all shares of Family Dollar at the $80 per share, $9.1 billion price point it set earlier. The bid expires…

Dollar General (DG) on Tuesday raised its Family Dollar (FDO) bid by 2% to $9.1 billion, or $80 a share, putting pressure on the takeover target to abandon its deal with Dollar Tree (DLTR).Family Dollar has not yet backed Dollar General's offers, citing the $500 million break-up fee and antitrust concerns, and is standing by Dollar Tree's lower $8.5 billion, $74.50-a-share cash-and-stock deal.But the No. 1 deep discount retailer says it's willing to pay the break-up fee and divest up to 1,500 stores, up from a previous proposal of 700 stores, to clear regulators' concerns."In the event you refuse to engage with us regarding our revised proposal, we will consider taking our persuasive and superior proposal directly to your shareholders," Dollar General CEO Rick Dreiling said in a letter to Family Dollar's board on Tuesday.Dollar General shares rose 1.2% to 64.73 on the stock market today. Dollar Tree rose 1.6% to 54.50. Family Dollar, which has been trading well above either prior offer, rose 0.5%, or 38 cents, to 80.21.

While Whole Foods Market (WFM) has been fending off rising competition from the likes of Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and Kroger (KR) hawking natural and organic food, membership warehouse Costco (COST) might have stealthily pulled ahead in organic sales.

Costco's organic food sales are at a run rate of $4 billion, according to BMO Capital Markets analyst Kelly Bania, up from about $3 billion just six to nine months ago and "possibly now already eclipsing" industry leader Whole Foods' estimated $3.6 billion.

Costco shares fell more than 1% Friday. https://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/The stock has been building a flat base since February and has been trading below its 50-day line since breaking support at that level in mid-April.
Costco's expanding organics share could result in a slightly higher gross margin percentage and bolster its customer traffic growth outlook, says Bania, who has an outperform rating on the stock.

As the gap between the age of the average Costco member and the average American is already narrowing, Costco's growing organic presence could attract all-important younger shoppers and support "an outlook for Costco to connect with an increasingly important consumer group — millennials — where we believe Costco remains underpenetrated currently," wrote Bania.

Costco reported mixed results Wednesday as same-store sales dipped 1%, affected by currency headwinds and gas price deflation. Earnings rose 9% to $1.17, beating expectations by 2 cents, while revenue missed views for $26.63 billion with a 1% rise to $26.1 billion.
Meanwhile, Big Lots' (BIG) first-quarter earnings beat analyst estimates, but the discounter issued weak second-quarter guidance.
On Friday, Big Lots said that its Q1 EPS rose 20% to 60 cents, a penny above the 59 cents that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected. Sales were flat at $1.28 billion.
Same-store sales were up 1.6%, in line with the 1% to 2% jump that Big Lots was expecting.

"I'm pleased with our first-quarter sales results. After a difficult start to the quarter and harsh weather conditions in February, sales trends improved in March and April," said CEO David Campisi. "Our comps for Q1 were solidly in line with our guidance and increased for a fifth consecutive quarter."
For the current quarter, Big Lots sees EPS of 31 cents to 35 cents and same-store sales increasing 2% to 3%. Analysts are expecting earnings of 37 cents per share.
Big Lots raised the low end of its full-year EPS outlook to a range of $2.80 to $2.90, up from $2.75 to $2.90. Analysts had forecast $2.87.
The stock hit a January low but still appears to be forming a base.
On Thursday, rival Dollar General (DG) named Todd Vasos as its new CEO, effective June 3.

IBD's discount retail group ranked No. 168 out of 197 groups in Friday's edition. Costco is in the major discount chains group, which ranked No. 147.While Whole Foods Market (WFM) has been fending off rising competition from the likes of Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and Kroger (KR) hawking natural and organic food, membership warehouse Costco (COST) might have stealthily pulled ahead in organic sales.Costco's organic food sales are at a run rate of $4 billion, according to BMO Capital Markets analyst Kelly Bania, up from about $3 billion just six to nine months ago and "possibly now already eclipsing" industry leader Whole Foods' estimated $3.6 billion.Costco shares fell more than 1% Friday. https://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/The stock has been building a flat base since February and has been trading below its 50-day line since breaking support at that level in mid-April.Costco's expanding organics share could result in a slightly higher gross margin percentage and bolster its customer traffic growth outlook, says Bania, who has an outperform rating on the stock.As the gap between the age of the average Costco member and the average American is already narrowing, Costco's growing organic presence could attract all-important younger shoppers and support "an outlook for Costco to connect with an increasingly important consumer group — millennials — where we believe Costco remains underpenetrated currently," wrote Bania.Costco reported mixed results Wednesday as same-store sales dipped 1%, affected by currency headwinds and gas price deflation. Dollar General lost out on its bid to acquire Family Dollar Stores, but Wall Street doesn't seem too worried, as the stock continues to hold near highs amid robust expansion plans. In January, Family Dollar Stores (FDO) shareholders overwhelmingly approved Dollar Tree's  (DLTR) offer. It was lower than Dollar General's  (DG) but came with more regulatory certainty. When…
Stock futures nosed higher ahead of Monday's open as earnings news contended with the effects of a rising dollar.
Dow futures rose 28.6 points above fair market value, nearly doubling their gain from an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 9.9 points, also rising. S&P 500 futures kept to a 1.9-point gain.

The stock market today rolls out with the Nasdaq fighting to hold fresh highs inked late last week, while the S&P 500 presses against resistance marked at its May 20 high. Stocks set sail under a fresh market status , a plus for investors.

Banks reopened today in Greece, hinting at more progress toward whatever the new normal might be there. And with earnings season continuing to look somewhat better than forecast, the easing of overseas tension allowed currency traders to focus more directly on a potential rate increase by the Federal Reserve later this year. That sent the dollar surging in early trade Monday and placed some downward pressure on U.S. stocks.
The economic calendar is blank today, but picks up with a steady stream of housing data beginning on Wednesday.
In aerospace, Lockheed Martin (LMT) and United Technologies (UTX) each rose 1% after news reports said Lockheed agreed to buy United Tech's Sikorsky helicopter unit for more than $8 billion.
The deal, one of Lockheed's largest since its $10 billion combination with Martin Marietta in 1995, will give Lockheed United Technologies' Black Hawk helicopter business.

Morgan Stanley (MS) topped the early earnings news, climbing 3% after its second-quarter sales and earnings topped analyst projections. Revenue from bonds and securities trading surged 25%, while investment banking revenue slipped 1%. The stock ended Friday in buying range on a rebound from 10-week support.

Halliburton (HAL) ticked up 2% after its revenue and earnings declined less than expected in Q2. Earnings fell 52% and revenue slipped 27% vs. expectations for declines of 67% and 28%, respectively. Revenue in North America fell 39%. Halliburton shares fell in 10 of the past 11 weeks after a stalled attempt to climb out of a deep, 12-month consolidation.

The morning's injured list showed Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) down 8%, but paring some early losses. The Mississippi-based egg producer and distributor's fiscal Q4 revenue and earnings stopped well short of analyst expectations.

The company, focused primarily in Southern and Eastern markets, was widely seen by investors as missing many of the negative effects of the avian flu affecting much of the industry, while benefiting from the corresponding increase in egg prices. The stock ended Friday in a flattish consolidation, testing 10-week support below a May high.
Overseas, Europe's leading indexes sketched out moderate gains near midday. China's markets posted a narrowly mixed close, with Shanghai up, Hong Kong down. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 added 0.9%.

Gold fell nearly 2%, trading below $1,112 an ounce and at its lowest level since early 2010. Oil prices slipped a few pennies, with West Texas Intermediate trading near $50 a barrel. Dollar General (DG) may have lost the bidding war to merge with Family Dollar Stores (FDO) to rival Dollar Tree (DLTR).
But that shouldn't stop Dollar General from being a winner on other fronts.

In a report out Friday, Sterne Agee analyst Charles Grom offered key takeaways from meetings with Dollar General management the day before that lead him to see bright prospects for Dollar General, which he rates a buy.
The key soundbite from the meetings: "'There is no doubt the consumer is feeling better today' sums up an extremely upbeat trip," he noted.
He said management discussed a number of "drivers" that should combine to lead EPS upside in 2015.
Why is Dollar General primed to be a winner?
Strong Growth Record
1. A strong growth record is seen continuing.

Part of IBD's Retail-Discount & Variety group, Dollar General is a deep discounter. It ranks No. 1 in the group with an IBD Composite rating of 96 out of a possible 99, based on a variety of metrics such as earnings growth and stock-price gains.
The company has logged double-digit earnings growth in all but three of the past 16 quarters. And analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see it turning out double-digit earnings growth in 2015.
Sentiment, Pricing Trends Positive
2.Improving consumer sentiment and pricing trends bode well for the company.
Management noted that the company's consumer is "'feeling better' and currently enjoying 'more tailwinds than headwinds,'" said Grom.

The company's internal studies show that the retailer is currently priced "near parity to the mass channel (Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), Target (TGT) 'rational' environment) and has actually widened the gap versus the drug stores (roughly 200 basis points better than historical levels)," he notes.
Same-Store Momentum
3. Dollar General is poised to keep up its same-store sales momentum.

A number of sales-per-square foot "drivers currently in place give us confidence that Dollar General can keep the comp momentum going and improve on its industry-leading (sales-per-square foot) of around $202," Grom noted.

Key drivers include the discounter's "affordability" strategy launched last year. He says the strategy continues to "ramp up" with items priced for less than $5 contributing 75% of total company sales.

Another effort is digital coupons, with over 1 million sign-ups to date, says Grom. With this effort, the company is "effectively creating a loyalty card database (without the cost) and the ability to drive more personalized promotions going forward based on historical buying patterns," he noted.
Dollar General Store Expansion
4. Square footage growth is planned to accelerate in a big way, leading to market share gains.

Grom noted that the company has plans for roughly 6% square footage growth, or 730 stores, in fiscal 2015. Management "reiterated" in his visit that it would accelerate square footage growth in 2016 to 7%, or around 900 stores, he said.
Management "feels confident in the 6-7% growth range in the out years," he added.

"With peers Family Dollar and Dollar Tree (post merger) likely to undergo a multiyear consolidation period (i.e., re-bannering, closing, fixing), it's our view that DG sees this an opportunity to ramp growth — capturing better sites and market share along the way," Grom said.

Dollar General shares rose 0.3% to 74.99 on the stock market Friday. Stock futures showed weak gains ahead of Wednesday's start of trade, despite disappointing February durable goods data. Dow futures were 4.9 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 7.9 points. S&P 500 futures held a 1.3 point gain.Stock Market TodayThe stock market today opens still in a confirmed uptrend, but while the Nasdaq backed off slightly from its new high made Friday, the S&P 500 has not managed to push through its resistance. Distribution continues to rise , leaving investors good cause to remain cautious in making any new purchases.Economic NewsInterest rates dipped back to their lowest level in a month, spurring a 9.5% jump in mortgage applications, the Mortgage Bankers Association reported. Refinance applications climbed more than 12% during the week to 61% of total applications. But demand for loans to buy a home also rose smartly.New orders for durable goods slumped 1.4% in February, the Commerce Department reported. That followed January's 2.8% increase, and was far below consensus views for a 0.7% gain. Minus transportation, the numbers were less drastic, down 0.4% in February, vs. January's 0.3% rise and expectations for another 0.3% gain.The Energy Information Administration releases its weekly oil inventories report at 10:30 a.m. ET.StocksKraft Foods Group (KRFT) boiled up 35% in premarket action on an agreement to merge with ketchup-maker H.J. Heinz Co. The deal would create The Kraft Heinz Co., which the companies claim would be the third-largest food and beverage provider in North America. Kraft shareholders will own 51% of the new company and receive a special dividend of $16.50 per share. The dividend was to be funded by a $10 billion equity contribution from co-Heinz owners Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) and from 3G capital.Apollo Education (APOL) dived 17% after reporting fiscal second quarter a narrower-than-expected loss, but revenue and full-year guidance were below forecasts, hurt by weaker enrollment The stock almost recovered from a 10-month correction late last year, then rolled over into another deep dive.Nationstar Mortgage (NSM) slumped 8% ahead of the open. The mortgage services provider announced an offering of 17.5 million shares, with proceeds to be used for acquisitions, general purposes and debt. Nationstar said on Tuesday it had agreed to purchase a $25 billion loan servicing portfolio from Ocwen Financial (OCN). Nationstar shares have been climbing since mid-January, and this retook their 40-week moving average.OverseasMarkets across Asia closed narrowly mixed. Europe's leading indexes carried mild losses into midday trade. The Shanghai Composite and Tokyo's Nikkei 225 hung just below multi-year highs. In Germany, Frankfurt's DAX and London's FTSE 100 were just off its record high notched last week, while the CAC-40 in Paris traded just below a seven-year high.Currencies/CommoditiesThe dollar was down against the euro and the yen. Commodities were mixed and little changed.

Dollar General (DG) reported second-quarter earnings that matched estimates Thursday and said it was "firmly committed" to buying competitor Family Dollar Stores (FDO), which has said it will stick with another deep discounter's offer. The discount retailer's Q2 earnings rose 7.8% to 83 cents, in line with estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Sales climbed 7.5% to $4.72 billion…
CVS Caremark (CVS) is now CVS Health, and the nationwide drugstore chain is already living up to its new corporate name with the decision to extinguish tobacco sales ahead of schedule.
Shares of the company rose 0.4% to 80.02 in the stock market today.
The popular drugstore said in February that it would nix sales of tobacco products in the U.S. by Oct. 1, but the announcement today pushes those plans forward by almost a month.

"By eliminating the sale of cigarettes and tobacco products in our stores, we can make a difference in the health of all Americans," said CEO Larry Merlo in a statement on its new site. The company said it has launched a smoking cessation campaign, in addition to partnering with physicians to "provide clinical support, medication counseling, chronic disease monitoring and wellness programs for their members."
Following solid second-quarter results, CVS boosted its earnings guidance for the year.
Competitors Walgreen (WAG) and Rite Aid (RAD) continue to sell tobacco products, along with deep discounters such as Dollar General (DG)
Walgreen shares rose fractionally intraday Rite Aid shares fell 1.5%. Dollar General stock was unchanged.
Tobacco giant Altria (MO) edged lower.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter at IBD_Elow.

Family Dollar (FDO) turned down Dollar General's (DG) takeover bid Thursday but reportedly would still consider the offer if there were certainty that the deal would get regulatory approval.A Family Dollar analysis indicates that Dollar General would have to sell several hundred more stores for the deal to pass, sources told Bloomberg. Family Dollar's decision Thursday suggested that the current proposal to close 700 stores wouldn't be enough to risk spurning its lower-priced agreement with Dollar Tree (DLTR).But Wolfe Research analyst Scott Mushkin says that Family Dollar is exaggerating its antitrust concerns."While we acknowledge that regulators have sometimes taken narrow views when two retailers merge together, the bottom line is that even in the smallest markets that we have researched, the consumer has a multitude of options when buying ubiquitous consumables," said Mushkin in a research note published Friday.Mushkin added that Wal-Mart (WMT) has such a dominant market share that a "more formidable" Dollar General would actually help the competitive dynamics in many markets.Family Dollar shares ticked up 0.3% to 79.61 on the stock market today, remaining above Dollar Tree's offer of $74.50 a share and suggesting that investors expect a higher price tag. Shares of Dollar Tree and Dollar General were flat.Dollar General CEO Rick Dreiling has said he's confident that any antitrust issues could be quickly and efficiently resolved.Dollar Tree would still have the opportunity to match Dollar General's $78.50-a-share offer if Dollar General would agree to appease Family Dollar with additional divestments, Bloomberg said.RELATED:Video: Family Dollar Backs Dollar Tree Buyout Bid.
Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. Dow futures were level, trading 92.5 points above fair market value.
Nasdaq 100 futures and S&P 500 futures were also steady, up 33.4 and 11.4 points, respectively.

The stock market today has its work cut out for it, although Christmas week trade generally tends to be light. The young uptrend ran into heavy distribution Friday, raising questions as to how long it will last.

Economic news isn't likely to have much impact. The Chicago Federal Reserve's National Activity Index, the most prominent piece of economic news prior to the open, showed a 0.3% slip in November. That accelerated October's 0.17% contraction and was not what economist consensus had expected — a 0.15% increase.

International markets also appeared to have negligible effect. Stocks in Europe traded modestly higher at midday. China's markets rose, including a 1.8% jump from the Shanghai Composite, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan slipped 0.4%.

The dollar rose. Bonds edged up. Oil prices slipped, with West Texas Intermediate down 1%, bobbing between $34 and $35 a barrel, and Brent crude down 2% to just above $36. Most metals traded higher, but with no big gains.

There could be a "Star Wars" effect on early trade, with Walt Disney (DIS) being one of three stocks leading the Dow with a better-than 1% gain in premarket trade. Goldman Sachs (GS) and Apple (AAPL) also gained more than 1%.

Disney's "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" grossed an estimated $238 million in the U.S. and Canada over the weekend. That was above expectations, beating out prior record holders "Jurassic World," which grossed $208.8 million when it premiered in June, and "The Avengers," which pulled $207.4 million in its 2012 premier.
Disney shares briefly cleared a 117.678 buy point in a cup-with-handle base in November, then dropped and undercut the buy point by more than 8%, triggering a sell rule.

Huge-screen, 3D-savvy Imax (IMAX) jumped 3%. The new "Star Wars" film reportedly premiered on 667 Imax screens over the weekend, pulling in $48 million — setting an Imax record and topping the $44.1 million opening weekend take of "Jurassic World," according to box office figures from Deadline Hollywood. Imax, an IBD 50 stock, ended Friday about 2% below a 39.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Also on the IBD 50 list, ARM (ARMH) perked up 3% ahead of the open. Shares of the Cambridge, England-based chip designer tumbled 6% last week, ending below the stock's converged 10- and 40-week lines of support.Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. But Family Dollar Stores shares continued to trade above both offers, suggesting investors expect an ongoing battle. "Our board reviewed, with our advisers, all aspects of Dollar General's proposal and unanimously concluded that it…

Family Dollar Stores adopted a one-year poison-pill plan Monday after activist investor Carl Icahn late Friday disclosed a large stake in the specialty discounter. The shareholder-rights plan is triggered at 10%, just above the 9.39% stake Icahn disclosed on Twitter. He is now the largest shareholder of Family Dollar Stores (FDO). Poison pills are used to prevent hostile takeovers. "The…

Deep discounter Dollar General (DG) is the front-runner in the race to lure consumers with low prices, according to a pricing study by Sterne Agee analyst Charles Grom. The study compares prices at Dollar General, deep discounter Family Dollar Stores (FDO) and giant discounterWal-Mart Stores (WMT). Based on his recent round of price checks, Dollar General is the "new price…
Dollar General (DG) will accelerate new store openings next year after losing a bidding war for Family Dollar to rival Dollar Tree.
The discount retail giant plans to open 730 stores this year, representing 6% square footage growth, with another 875 stores to be relocated or remodeled.
Next year, square footage growth will pick up to 7%. The company citing "strong new store returns that have been consistently proven over the last six years."
Shares climbed 3% on the stock market today, helped by a $1 billion increase in its buyback plan and strong fourth-quarter revenue.

In Q4, Dollar General's earnings per share minus one-time items rose 16% to $1.17, meeting analysts' forecasts, on a nearly 10% hike in revenue to $4.94 billion. Analysts expected $4.5 billion in revenue.
Sales at stores open at least a year grew 4.9%, and CEO Rick Dreiling said that the Q4 results "reflect accelerating same-store sales."
For the next fiscal year, Dollar General sees EPS of $3.85-$3.95, below the consensus for $4, and revenue growth of 8%-9% vs. Wall Street views for 8.6%. Same-store sales are seen up 3%-5%.
The company also announced that CFO David Tehle will retire, effective July 1, and that it has begun a search for a replacement.

In January, Dollar General lost a bidding war for Family Dollar Stores (FDO) when shareholders of that company rejected its sweetened $9.1 billion offer and voted instead to accept rival Dollar Tree's (DLTR) offer. The merger will make the combined company the largest U.S. discount chain.

Stocks jumped out of the starting gate in firm trade Thursday, despite a mixed bag of economic news.
The Dow Jones industrial average bolted 0.9% higher. The S&P 500 climbed 0.7%. The Nasdaq tacked on a 0.4% gain.

The stock market today got off to a positive start, as investors weighed a much-better-than-expected unemployment claims report against a surprise tumble in February retail sales. European markets were mixed, with London's FTSE 100 index jumping 1% in afternoon trade. Oil prices pushed higher, with Europe's Brent crude up nearly 2% and above $58 per barrel.

Export prices weakened 0.1% in February, the Labor Department reported, slower than January's 0.2% decline and in line with consensus expectations. Import prices climbed 0.4%, vs. a 2.8% decline in January. Economists had projected a 0.2% gain.
In stocks, American Express (AXP) and Walt Disney (DIS) led the Dow, up 2% each.

Dollar General (DG) ordered up a 3% gain after a no-frills fourth quarter report. Earnings and revenue met expectations. Full year revenue guidance was in line with projections. Earnings guidance was a bit low, but not enough to fluster investors. The gain lifted shares to a new high, 2% above a 71.80 flat base buy point.

Chip stocks were taking early hits, with Intel (INTC) and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) both down 4%. Intel trimmed almost a billion dollars from its Q1 revenue guidance, because of weak desktop PC demand and low inventory levels. It kept its gross margin guidance steady at 60%.
Monster Beverage (MNST) headed up the IBD 50 list with a 2% gain. The energy-drink maker is hovering just below its Feb. 27 high, and 22% above a flat base buy point of 113.60.

India's HDFC Bank (HDB) also jumped 2%, rising from support at its 10-week moving average following a five-day pullback. Stocks stepped out to healthy opening gains Monday, with an added boost from solid August housing market data.
The Dow Jones industrial average kicked up 0.8% at the start of trade. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 rolled ahead 0.7% each.
The stock market today opened to sharply lower volume — down 59% on the NYSE and 47% lower on the Nasdaq — no surprise in comparison with Friday's options expiration-boosted trade.

In economic new, builder confidence increased for a third straight month, lifting the National Association of Home Builders' Housing Market Index to 55 for August. That is up from July's 53 reading, the index's highest reading since January and easily above economist forecasts for a flat reading of 53.

Dollar General (DG) posted the morning's headline gain, up 9% after bidding $8.95 billion to acquire peer Family Dollar (FDO). The all-cash offer topped an earlier, $8.5 billion cash and stock offer made by Dollar Tree (DLTR). The news sent Family Dollar 5% higher. Dollar Tree slumped 2%.

Leading stocks scored one of the best starts in a while, with nearly all of the IBD 50 list advancing at the opening bell and nearly 20% of the list jumping 2% or more, although many gains quickly narrowed.

KapStone Paper & Packaging (KS) led the initial advance, jumping 3% after Deutsche Bank upgraded the stock to buy from hold. The report also raised the stock's target price to 36 from 26. KapStone has been trading wide and loose, but holding 40-week support, since a breakout attempt failed in July.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) edged up more than 1%, despite a Deustche Bank reports that trimmed the company's full-year earnings outlook. The note shaved 9% from Tesla's 2014 EPS estimate due to the company strengthening its warranty support of the Model S drivetrain.

Shoppers spent at a healthy clip last week as they unleashed pent-up demand for spring and early summer goods after hibernating during the cold winter, leading to an uptick in a key chain-store sales gauge released Tuesday.The International Council of Shopping Centers-Goldman Sachs chain-store sales index rose by 0.4% for the week ended June 14 from the prior week's adjusted level. That followed a 2.8% decline for the week ended June 7.Last week's gauge increased a strong 3.1% vs. a year earlier on a seasonally adjusted basis. That followed a 3% year-over-year rise for the prior week and a 3.1% gain for the week before that.The ICSC-GS consumer tracking survey found that business last week was up sharply year-over-year for wholesale clubs, and up "appreciably" for apparel, dollar, furniture, discount, office and department stores.That was likely good news for warehouse club operators such as Costco Wholesale (COST), discounters such as Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Target (TGT) as well as deep discounters like Dollar Tree (DLTR) andDollar General (DG). Office supply retailers such as Staples (SPLS), furniture retailers such as Haverty Furniture (HVT) and Ethan Allen Interiors (ETH) and department store operators includingMacy's (M) also likely benefited from the positive business trend."The overall retail strength was impressive, especially given the weather drag on sales," said the report.Last week's weather was somewhat cooler than last year and above the long-term "normal average" for the week, it noted.May same-store sales reported on June 5 moderated from April but were still up a strong 4.6% from a year earlier for the 11 major chains tracked by Michael Niemira, chief economist for the ICSC."It appears that after a winter when consumers deferred spending due to adverse weather, the consumer spring arrived as they picked up their spending pace in April and May," the report said.Niemira forecasts that June monthly same-store sales will rise by about 3.5% from a year earlier with a "slightly tougher year-ago comparison than was the case for May."

It was the first decline since Feb. 22, when the index slipped 0.6%. And…
Stocks were well off their lows at midday Tuesday after a jump in U.S. and European bond yields pointed to higher borrowing costs.

Just over two hours into the session, the Nasdaq was off 0.4%, the S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was running higher compared with the same time Monday.

The major averages were down as much as 1% early in the session after yields on 10-year U.S. and European bonds rose to their highest levels in five months. On Monday, the yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury note surged 13 basis points to 2.28%.
In the stock market today, Gap (GPS) fell 3% in heavy volume after the apparel retailer reported weaker-than-expected April same-store sales.

The Commercial Services-Outsourcing industry group was among the day's worst performing, weighed down by WageWorks' (WAGE) 17% plunge. Let's say that perfect stock you've been watching has finally cleared its buy point in heavy volume, setting off a screaming buy signal.You're tempted to go all-in because the stock's fundamentals are strong and the base was beautiful. But wait. What happens if the market tanks, or there's some bad news that sends the stock tumbling? You could lose a big chunk of change in a hurry.Rather than investing all of your allotted capital at once, consider making a few, progressively smaller purchases at key points as the stock moves up from its buy point. This concept, called pyramiding, was developed by legendary investor Jesse Livermore as a way of reducing risk.Typically, you would spend half of your allotted capital when the stock breaks out above its buy point. Then invest another 30% if the stock rises 2%-2.5% from the buy point and the remaining 20% if the stock climbs 4%-5% above the entry.It's true you'd make more money if you invested the full amount at the breakout, assuming the stock continued to rise. But it's also true that you'd lose more if the stock were to fall.For example, if you invest all of your $10,000 savings in a stock that ends up falling 8% below the purchase price — triggering the golden sell rule — you'd lose $800. If you start with half of a position, you'd lose just $400.In this way, pyramiding requires the stock to prove itself before you put more money to work. Yet "averaging up" isn't commonly used by investors."Most of them average down, meaning they buy additional shares as a stock declines in price in order to lower their cost per share," IBD founder William J. O'Neil wrote in "How To Make Money In Stocks." "Why add more of your hard-earned money to stocks that aren't working?"Dollar General (DG) behaved well following its breakout. The stock cleared a 35.19 buy point in a flat base on Aug. 30, 2011. Volume was 174% above normal.The stock boasted a near-perfect 98 Composite Rating, putting it in the top 2% of all stocks based on five key IBD metrics. Its B+ Accumulation-Distribution Rating indicated strong demand.An investor using the pyramiding technique would have made an initial purchase at the breakout. A second buy between 35.89 and 36.07 could have been established a few days later on Sept. 2, (1) when the stock rose more than 2% past the 35.19 entry.Dollar General pulled back for two sessions to as low as 34.22. (2) It was not severe enough to force an investor to sell the first or second batch of shares. The stock found its footing and continued to climb. A final buy between 36.60 and 36.95 could have been made Sept. 14 as it rose more than 4% past the initial buy point. (3) Dollar General hit as high as 56.04 in July 2012, up 59%.You can also pyramid when the stock forms a new base or pulls back lightly to the 10-week line for the first or second time.

Major averages traded in a tight range Wednesday, ending with modest losses.The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P; 500 and Nasdaq each lost 0.2%. Small caps came out ahead, with the Russell 2000 up 0.6%. Preliminary data in the stock market today showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in lower than Tuesday's levels.After the close, recent new issue Shake Shack (SHAK) reported a 51% jump in quartely sales, but shares slumped 7% in early after-hours trading. Shake Shake met the same fate as fellow burger chain Habit Restaurants (HABT). Earlier today, the burger chain reported another quarter of strong sales growth, but it warned of slower growth in the second half of 2015. In the regular session, Habit slumped 8%.It was a different story for fast-casual chain Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES). Investors cheered its earnings report, sending shares higher by 4% in the after-hours sessionIn the regular session, Intel (INTC) advanced 2% in strong volume, making it the day's biggest gainer on the Dow. The stock's chart, however, is a mess. Intel is under its 50-day and 200-day lines, and the 50-day line is declining, all of which is bearish. The stock's relative strength line has been falling since mid-January, another negative sign.Valeant (VRX) scored a new high early but reversed on reports that Endo International (ENDP) is interested in acquiring Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP). Last month, Valeant bid $14.5 billion for Salix, valuing it at around 158 a share. Valeant lost 4%. Endo also reversed after early strength, falling just over 1%. Salix gained 7%.Economic data on tap for Thursday include February retail sales and weekly jobless claims.On the earnings front, watch for reports from Springleaf Holdings (LEAF), Cantel Medical (CMN) and Dollar General (DG) before the open.

Stocks opened with an uptick Thursday, then quickly turned mixed despite a strong dose of support from economic data and reports.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.2%. The Nasdaq reversed early gains and slipped 0.2%, and the S&P 500 added 0.1%. Volume was also mixed, up 3% on the NYSE and 25% lower on the Nasdaq.

The stock market today sets out with the current uptrend in good standing. Plenty of headlines rolled out overnight — intensified fighting in Ukraine, weak manufacturing data out of China — that would have shaken a timid market. A rising dollar also added pressure which, in many cases, would work against early stock gains.

Stocks opened to a better-than-expected reading on weekly unemployment claims. In addition, U.S. manufacturing rebounded from a three-month low in July, lifting Markit's preliminary August U.S. Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index to 58, up sharply from July's 55.8. That was its highest reading in four years.

Existing-home sales climbed to their highest annualized rate of the year, 5.15 million units, the National Association of Realtors reported. Sales have increased for four straight months but remain below year-ago levels.

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Business Outlook Survey jumped to 28 for August, its third consecutive gain and highest reading since March 2011. Analysts had projected a slowdown to 20, from July's 23.9 reading. Broad indicators of future activity increased, but new orders, shipments, and employment fell from July's levels.

Growth also accelerated in the Conference Board's Leading Economic Index, up 0.9% in July, vs. 0.6% gains in the prior two months. The signals suggest "the economy is gaining traction" the group said in a statement, "and growth should continue at a strong pace for the remainder of the year."

It was a relatively quiet morning in the company-news front. Bank of America (BAC) rose 1% on word of its record-setting $16.65 billion settlement with the Department of Justice. Dollar General (DG) and Family Dollar Stores (FDO) slipped a fraction each after announcing Family Dollar had rejected its peer's $9 billion takeover bid. Family Dollar reaffirmed its prior $8.5 billion agreement with Dollar Tree (DLTR). (Dollar Tree shares slipped 2% after Q3 earnings missed analyst consensus views.)
Among leaders, Autohome (ATHM) fell 4%.

The China-based provider of online automotive information has been diligently building the right side of a five-month IPO base. The base is 45% deep, increasing the risk weighing against any breakout it might produce.

Illumina (ILMN) gained 3% at the open. The San Diego, Calif.-based maker of genetic screening technologies announced a strategic partnership with AstraZeneca (AZN), Janssen and Sanofi (SNY) to develop a universal next-generation sequencing-based oncology test system. Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. Dow futures were level, trading 92.5 points above fair market value.
Nasdaq 100 futures and S&P 500 futures were also steady, up 33.4 and 11.4 points, respectively.

The stock market today has its work cut out for it, although Christmas week trade generally tends to be light. The young uptrend ran into heavy distribution Friday, raising questions as to how long it will last.

Economic news isn't likely to have much impact. The Chicago Federal Reserve's National Activity Index, the most prominent piece of economic news prior to the open, showed a 0.3% slip in November. That accelerated October's 0.17% contraction and was not what economist consensus had expected — a 0.15% increase.

International markets also appeared to have negligible effect. Stocks in Europe traded modestly higher at midday. China's markets rose, including a 1.8% jump from the Shanghai Composite, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan slipped 0.4%.

The dollar rose. Bonds edged up. Oil prices slipped, with West Texas Intermediate down 1%, bobbing between $34 and $35 a barrel, and Brent crude down 2% to just above $36. Most metals traded higher, but with no big gains.

There could be a "Star Wars" effect on early trade, with Walt Disney (DIS) being one of three stocks leading the Dow with a better-than 1% gain in premarket trade. Goldman Sachs (GS) and Apple (AAPL) also gained more than 1%.

Disney's "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" grossed an estimated $238 million in the U.S. and Canada over the weekend. That was above expectations, beating out prior record holders "Jurassic World," which grossed $208.8 million when it premiered in June, and "The Avengers," which pulled $207.4 million in its 2012 premier.
Disney shares briefly cleared a 117.678 buy point in a cup-with-handle base in November, then dropped and undercut the buy point by more than 8%, triggering a sell rule.

Huge-screen, 3D-savvy Imax (IMAX) jumped 3%. The new "Star Wars" film reportedly premiered on 667 Imax screens over the weekend, pulling in $48 million — setting an Imax record and topping the $44.1 million opening weekend take of "Jurassic World," according to box office figures from Deadline Hollywood. Imax, an IBD 50 stock, ended Friday about 2% below a 39.97 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Also on the IBD 50 list, ARM (ARMH) perked up 3% ahead of the open. Shares of the Cambridge, England-based chip designer tumbled 6% last week, ending below the stock's converged 10- and 40-week lines of support.Stock futures held steady, healthy gains ahead of Monday's open as the market looked toward a short week of preholiday trade. Dow futures were level, trading 92.5 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures and S&P 500 futures were also steady, up 33.4 and 11.4 points, respectively.The stock market today has its work cut out for it, although Christmas week trade generally tends to be light. The young uptrend ran into heavy distribution Friday, raising questions as to how long it will last.Economic news isn't likely to have much impact. The Chicago Federal Reserve's National Activity Index, the most prominent piece of economic news prior to the open, showed a 0.3% slip in November. That accelerated October's 0.17% contraction and was not what economist consensus had expected — a 0.15% increase.International markets also appeared to have negligible effect. Stocks in Europe traded modestly higher at midday. China's markets rose, including a 1.8% jump from the Shanghai Composite, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan slipped 0.4%.The dollar rose. Bonds edged up. Oil prices slipped, with West Texas Intermediate down 1%, bobbing between $34 and $35 a barrel, and Brent crude down 2% to just above $36. Most metals traded higher, but with no big gains.There could be a "Star Wars" effect on early trade, with Walt Disney (DIS) being one of three stocks leading the Dow with a better-than 1% gain in premarket trade. The Williams-Sonoma store on Manhattan's Upper East Side drew a nice crowd during its summer clearance sale on the last Wednesday in July.

But customers weren't only drawn to the bargains. They were also snapping up pricier items like carving boards that cost $79.95 to $99.95 and bottles of organic olive oil for $24.95, while at least one browser eyed a Nespresso Maestria Espresso machine for $699.95.
Judging from its financial results,Williams-Sonoma (WSM) doesn't need a sale to lure customers or deliver solid profit growth.

The luxury home goods retail operator has grown earnings by at least double digits in all but two of the past 16 quarters. During this year's first quarter it logged a 17% year-over-year increase in EPS and 10% gains in both overall sales and comparable brand sales.
Tiffany, Kors Shine

Williams-Sonoma isn't the only luxury retailer on a roll. In the first quarter, upscale jewelers Tiffany & Co. (TIF) andSignet Jewelers (SIG) and high-end fashion house Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) all posted double-digit earnings growth, while luxury home furnishings retailer Restoration Hardware (RH) saw a triple-digit gain.

In contrast, retailers that target the middle- and lower-income consumer — including deep discounters Family Dollar Stores (FDO) and Dollar General (DG) as well as giant discounter Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) — reported little or no growth during the latest quarter.
As a group, luxury retailers have outpaced the broader market since the first quarter of 2010 and discounters since the fourth quarter of 2009.

The luxury group's Q1 profit rose 9% from the prior year. That compares with a 7% drop for the discount group and a 4.5% decline for the retail industry, says Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics.
Luxury retailers typically cater to consumers with an annual household income above $100,000. For obvious reasons, these consumers can spend more freely than those who make less money.

Affluent consumers have benefited from the rise both in real estate and equity markets during the economic recovery, Perkins says. Most moderate-to-low-income consumers did not benefit from these assets.

In addition, Perkins added, "the economy has been unable to generate enough well-paying jobs to generate a higher level of consumer spending. That's had an impact on many middle- and lower-income consumers. Their wages are stagnant or in decline."
Analyst Bradley Thomas, who covers retail hardlines for KeyBanc Capital Markets, offers a similar take.
"There's definitely a bifurcation, he said. "Clearly, the wealth effect is the tailwind for high-end retailers and manufacturers."

Williams-Sonoma and Restoration Hardware have had "standout results," Thomas says. But chains that are more exposed to low-income consumers — such as rent-to-own operators Rent-A-Center (RCII) and Aaron's (AAN) — have had a "fair amount of weakness this year."
The low-end consumer also has been faced with a "litany of small cost increases that really add up," Thomas says. These include a reduction in food stamp benefits and unemployment benefits.
Luxury retailers, meantime, have done their fair share to lure consumers.
Take Williams-Sonoma, whose lineup of retail operations includes Williams-Sonoma, Pottery Barn and West Elm. It has seen double-digit profit growth in all but one of the past nine quarters.
Thomas says one reason for the company's strong results "comes down to their omnichannel model, which it does better than just about anyone."
"Omnichannel" refers to the fact that each of the company's brands sells through its own stores, online and through their catalogs.

"Williams-Sonoma has omnichannel in their DNA dating back to their heritage as a catalog business, which has translated very well into being an online business as well as a brick-and-mortar retailer," Thomas said.

In a July report initiating coverage on Williams-Sonoma with a "buy" rating, Nomura analyst Jessica Schoen Mace said the company's "numerous store formats, strong retail brands and established e-commerce presence (44% of the business) should result in continued market-share growth both in the U.S. and internationally."
This in turn should help Williams-Sonoma exceed its planned mid- to high single-digit revenue growth and low- double-digit to mid-teens EPS growth, Mace added.
Real Estate Restoration

Restoration Hardware has also been a standout, with a long run of double-digit or better earnings and sales growth. The company is undergoing a real estate transformation that involves scrapping some smaller stores in favor of bigger ones, including Full Line Design Galleries of 25,000 to 60,000 square feet.
As part of the transformation, Restoration Hardware is also revamping its supply chain and system platform. These initiatives have helped the company deliver industry-leading same-store sales gains.
But times have been tough on the discount front — so tough that even the world's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart, has seen several quarters of declining U.S. same-store sales.

Company officials hope a management shakeup will help turn things around. On July 24, Wal-Mart announced that its U.S. CEO, Bill Simon, is stepping down and being succeeded by Greg Foran, president and CEO of Wal-Mart Asia.

Wal-Mart's core customer "has been under pressure since the recovery," Perkins said. "It's being forced to broaden its online effort to bring in more customers, and to expand its (small-format) Neighborhood Market stores to capture some of the business they've been losing to Dollar Tree (DLTR) and Dollar General."
Perkins points out that Simon noted just last month that the middle-to-low-end consumer has not seen much recovery.
Deep Discount Powerhouse

Meanwhile, Wal-Mart might be facing more competition. Deep discounter Dollar Tree, which sells everything for $1 or less, announced on July 28 that it had agreed to buy struggling Family Dollar in an $8.5 billion deal that would create a new No. 1 player in the deep discount space and create a 13,000-store retail powerhouse.

The merger should result in improvements at Family Dollar, says Wedbush analyst Joan Storms. "It clearly would improve its merchandise assortment. That will lead to increased store productivity and operating margin expansion, which would make it a stronger competitor to the likes of Wal-Mart (smaller format) Express stores."
One thing many agree on is that the bifurcation between the low-end and high-end retail consumer will continue.
"It's not because the 'have nots' are getting worse, but because the 'haves' are getting better faster," said Joel Bines, managing director at consultancy AlixPartners.

This has allowed luxury retailers to increase prices and create an even bigger separation between the two segments, he says. "This also puts enormous pressure on retailers who cater to the lower-end consumer since they can't grow by raising prices."The Williams-Sonoma store on Manhattan's Upper East Side drew a nice crowd during its summer clearance sale on the last Wednesday in July.But customers weren't only drawn to the bargains. They were also snapping up pricier items like carving boards that cost $79.95 to $99.95 and bottles of organic olive oil for $24.95, while at least one browser eyed a Nespresso Maestria Espresso machine for $699.95.Judging from its financial results,Williams-Sonoma (WSM) doesn't need a sale to lure customers or deliver solid profit growth.The luxury home goods retail operator has grown earnings by at least double digits in all but two of the past 16 quarters. Expect more mergers and acquisitions in retail as strong cash flow, low interest rates and double-digit e-commerce growth entice management teams and boards to "create value" and position their companies for the long term.
So said ISI Group analysts in a retail M&A report published on Sunday.
The team selected three retailers that they consider the best M&A targets: Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), PetSmart (PETM) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM).
Why those names? All three companies, they said, offer "the most interesting combination of low debt, reasonable valuation and best growth prospects" of 15 retailers that they studied.

The ISI analysts said that private equity or activist investors prefer retailers that are still growing rather than shrinking. Dick's, PetSmart and Williams-Sonoma fit that bill, but the analysts don't know of any specific deals in play.
They're "worth considering," said Michael Montani, one of the report's authors, in a brief phone interview. "These are the companies that look the most attractive as potential targets."
The next most attractive M&A candidates cited in the report were Hibbett Sports (HIBB), Cabela's (CAB) and Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY).
Some of the top names on the list could be buyers rather than targets, Montani said.
Not so attractive M&A candidates are Staples (SPLS), Office Depot (ODP), Best Buy (BBY) and HH Gregg (HGG), whose toplines are shrinking, he says.

The report notes that industry consolidation could help increase productivity and reduce excess capacity. The recent bidding war between Dollar General (DG) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) for Family Dollar (FDO) "highlights the potential to rationalize dollar-store capacity," the analysts said.

For example, they said that dollar stores are saturated in the eastern half of the U.S. and that if Dollar General were to win Family Dollar, then Family Dollar would provide Dollar General with an opportunity to expand into the less saturated western half and create a "rational duopoly" with Dollar Tree.

The team didn't look at retailers trading above 10 times enterprise value/EBITDA — it would make a high teens return on invested capital tough. Nor did it consider stocks with market caps over $50 billion, which would likely attract very few bidders or require a consortium of bidders.Expect more mergers and acquisitions in retail as strong cash flow, low interest rates and double-digit e-commerce growth entice management teams and boards to "create value" and position their companies for the long term.So said ISI Group analysts in a retail M&A report published on Sunday.The team selected three retailers that they consider the best M&A targets: Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), PetSmart (PETM) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM).Why those names? At a time when the aggressive discounting is the name of the game for many retailers, even the discounters are lowering prices. But top drugstore chains have ticked prices up a bit. Those are some of the findings in a pricing survey done at the end of January by Sterne Agee analyst Charles Grom. The study involved a basket of…

Dollar General (DG) reported first-quarter profits Tuesday in line with views, but the discount variety chain lowered its full-year guidance, citing moderating sales and lower margins as its core low-income customers face ongoing financial pressures. Shares were down 7% in afternoon trading on the stock market today Dollar General said earnings grew 13% to 71 cents a share, matching forecasts…

Family Dollar Stores (FDO) fell short of quarterly earnings views, increasing speculation about the company's future as a stand-alone company. The discount retailer's Q3 EPS fell 19% to 85 cents, missing views for 89 cents and marking the fourth time in the last five quarters that earnings have come in lower. Revenue climbed 3.3% to $2.66 billion, slightly above estimates.…

Dollar Tree's agreement to buy Family Dollar Stores in a cash-and-stock deal valued at about $8.5 billion would create a new No. 1 in the deep discount retail market. The deal, announced early Monday, would give the combined company clout to compete not only with No. 1 dollar-store chain Dollar General (DG) but also with big-box discounters such as Wal-Mart…

Dollar Tree's agreement to buy Family Dollar Stores in a cash-and-stock deal valued at about $8.5 billion would create a new No. 1 in the deep discount retail market. The deal, announced early Monday, would give the combined company clout to compete not only with No. 1 dollar-store chain Dollar General (DG) but also with big-box discounters such as Wal-Mart…

Deep discounter Dollar General took the lead in the quest to draw consumers with low prices, according to a pricing study by Sterne Agee analyst Charles Grom.The study compares prices at Dollar General (DG), deep discounter Family Dollar Stores (FDO), and giant discounter Wal-Mart Stores (WMT).Based on Grom's most recent round of prices checks, Family Dollar's prices fell sequentially vs. his last study in mid-April, while both Wal-Mart and Dollar General's prices were up.Still, Dollar General's basket was priced around 40 basis points lower than the overall baskets at both Family Dollar and Wal-Mart.Grom's "dollar store" studies follow Family Dollar's announcement earlier this year that it would be investing $50 million in prices across 1,000 stock-keeping units (SKUs), or items, as part of a move back to everyday low pricing.Relative to the mid-April study, prices rose 0.5% sequentially at Dollar General and 0.3% at Wal-Mart in Grom's latest study.A 2% rise in consumables items prices at Dollar General moved its basket price higher, while the Wal-Mart basket increase came from the food and beverage category.The total basket of 42 SKUs declined 10 basis points at Family Dollar to $149.39, as lower prices in household products and in food and beverages offset rising prices in consumables.Dollar General "maintains price leadership as (the) gap continues to narrow," Grom notes.Even more interesting than the fact that Dollar General's basket price was 40 basis points lower than that of Family Dollar and Wal-Mart, he noted, is how closely all three baskets are priced.In the recent study, Family Dollar's basket at $149.39 was 0.4%, or 64 cents, higher than Dollar General's, compared to last May when the spread between Wal-Mart and Family Dollar was $7.81 or 5.3%.The dollar stores are getting much more competitive in food and beverages, Grom noted. Wal-Mart's prices in this category, which were once as much as 12% lower than the dollar stores, are now just 3.5% lower, he tallied.Prices were down around 2% from June 2013 at the dollar stores and up 2.4% at Wal-Mart. The total basket price fell 1.8% vs. last June at Dollar General and 2.1% at Family Dollar.Family Dollar stock has risen 17% this month, and Dollar General stock has moved up 14%, while Wal-Mart stock has moved down 1% as of late-afternoon trading in the stock market today.
The stock market made a bullish reversal Monday as it again found support at recent lows.

The S&P; 500 climbed 1.3%, leading the market thanks in part to a rebound in energy stocks and strength in financials. The index found support around the 2000 level, where it has done so for several weeks.
The Nasdaq closed 0.9% higher as the composite defended a floor around 4600. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.1%.

Volume fell sharply across the board, according to unconfirmed figures. While an increase in trading would have made Monday's gains look better, market breadth was decidedly bullish in the stock market today. Winners topped losers by nearly 3-to-1 on the NYSE and by 12-to-7 on the Nasdaq.

On Tuesday, automakers will report their January sales. In earnings reports, announcements are expected from Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG), Gilead Sciences (GILD), Edwards Lifesciences (EW) and United Parcel Service (UPS).The stock market made a bullish reversal Monday as it again found support at recent lows.The S&P; 500 climbed 1.3%, leading the market thanks in part to a rebound in energy stocks and strength in financials. Closeout retailer Big Lots' (BIG) shares spiked 13% after Q1 earnings and sales topped views as the company moves to tighten operations.

Big Lots' earnings dropped 18% from the year-earlier quarter to 50 cents a share, but that still beat analysts' expectations by 6 cents. The company reported that sales rose 1.1% to $1.28 billion, beating estimates of $1.26 billion.
In a post-earnings conference call, CEO David Campisi said that Q1 sales "could have been better," joining other retailers in blaming the severe winter weather for lower-than-desired seasonal sales.

In November 2013, the company had announced that it planned to close its wholesale operations and liquidate inventory in an effort to focus on retail operations, and in December announced that it planned to close its Canadian operations as well.
The company set guidance for the next quarter at 24 to 30 cents, and $2.35 to $2.50 for the year, up from previous estimates of $2.25 to $2.45.
Big Lots shares were up 13% to 42.40 in the stock market today.

Last week, fellow discount retailer Dollar Tree (DLTR) reported that Q1 EPS rose 13.6% to 67 cents, beating views by a penny. Sales rose 7% to $2 billion, a touch below expectations. Shares were down 1%.
Family Dollar Stores (FDO) reported Q2 earnings in April, with EPS down 34% to 80 cents, missing views by 10 cents. Revenue dropped 6% to $2.7 billion, also missing. Shares were mostly unchanged.
Dollar General (DG) is expected to report earnings on June 3. Analysts expect EPS to rise 3% to 73 cents and sales to jump 7.7% to $4.56 billion. Shares fell 0.5%.

Five Below (FIVE) will report after the close on June 4, with analysts expecting Q1 EPS of 6 cents, up from 5 cents a year ago. They expect sales to rise 27.5% to almost $122 million. The discount dollar-store chain's shares dipped slightly last week after it was cut from buy to neutral by Sterne Agee. Dollar General doesn't only face increasing competition from other dollar stores, but also from big-box bargain retailers such…

Shares of Dollar General (NYSE: DG) fell after fourth-quarter sales and forecasts for 2014 fell below Wall Street's targets.The nation's largest dollar-store chain by market capitalization said that, as with many retailers, harsh winter weather across much of the nation kept customers away.Dollar General's (DG) revenue rose 7% to $4.49 billion, but analysts were looking for $4.62 billion. Same-store sales rose 1.3%. Earnings per share edged up 4% to $1.01, matching views.The deep discounter remains cautious on the U.S. economic outlook and forecast Q1 EPS of 72-74 cents, well below the analyst consensus of 81 cents a share.It sees Q1 sales rising 7%-8%, with same-store sales up 2%-3%. Analysts see total sales advancing 9.8%.For the full year, Dollar General expects EPS of $3.45-$3.55 on a sales gain of 8%-9%. Wall Street projects EPS of $3.69 on sales growth of 10.1%.The company also said it expects to be impacted this year by higher health care costs associated with ObamaCare mandates.Sterne Agee analyst Chuck Grom said in a note that Dollar General had an "okay" Q4, noting good news in gross profit margin control, tight inventories, and expense discipline.On the downside, Grom said, comparable store sales were light and the company's guidance "was a touch worse than expected."Sterne Agee kept a buy rating and 63 price target for the company, but cut its full year EPS estimate to $3.53-$4.15, higher than the company's outlook but down from $3.65-$4.20 earlier.Sterne Agee also warned in the note that soft sales for Dollar General "read negatively" for smaller rival Family Dollar Stores (FDO), which the broker currently rates at "underperform."Dollar General shares were down 3% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Family Dollar Stores slid 1.7%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.
Dollar General (DG) bucked rival Dollar Tree's (DLTR) previous downside earnings surprise, as heavier traffic helped send third-quarter earnings above consensus estimates.

The Goodletsville, Tenn.-based dollar chain earned 72 cents a share, up 14% from last year and 2 cents over views. Sales rose 11% to $4.38 billion vs. forecasts of $4.42 billion. Same-store sales increased 4.4%.

It saw increases in customer traffic and average transaction value. Sales of consumables, led by tobacco products, perishables, and candy and snacks, grew at a higher rate than nonconsumables did. Seasonal and home products sales growth were "solid."

Shares were up 6%, hitting a new intraday high, in early-afternoon trading in the stock market today. Teen-focused discounter Five Below (FIVE) was up 2% ahead of its earnings release after the market closes.

Dollar General raised the low end of its full-year profit guidance to $3.18-$3.22, from the $3.15-$3.22 it saw earlier. That implies Q4 EPS of $1.01-$1.05. Analysts expect EPS of $1.04 in Q4 and $3.22 for the full year.
The company narrowed its full-year sales growth forecast slightly to 10%-10.5% from 10%-11%, including a 4%-4.5% bump in same-store sales. Analysts are looking for an overall 10.7% increase.
It also said its board authorized an additional $1 billion in share repurchases, bringing the total future buyback amount to $1.2 billion.

Dollar General's report was in stark contrast to rival discounter Dollar Tree, which suffered an almost 5% drop Nov. 21 after its Q3 results missed views, and it guided Q4 and full-year sales and earnings below the Street's consensus.

Stocks ended lower Thursday ahead of a key jobs report that could determine when the Federal Reserve will start scaling back its massive stimulus program. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.4% and the Nasdaq edged down 0.1%. Volume fell 15% on the NYSE and was down a fraction on the Nasdaq compared to Wednesday,…
Stocks got a mixed launch Thursday, seeking equilibrium after a volatile response to Wednesday's Federal Reserve policy announcement.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2% and the S&P 500 backed off 0.1%.
The stock market today opened in mixed volume, up 12% on the NYSE and 2% lower on the Nasdaq, compared to action at the same time Wednesday.

Mid-Atlantic region manufacturing slowed in March, according to the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey. The index dipped to 5, from 5.2 in January. Economists had projected a step up to 7.

Leading economic indicators were lukewarm, with the Conference Board reporting its Leading Economic Index up 0.2% in February — equal to January's increase and just below the 0.3% increase expected by analysts.

Oil prices were down hard after spiking late Wednesday. The 10 worst declines in the S&P 500 index were energy and mining issues, which led the market's rally late Wednesday. Chevron (CVX) and Caterpillar (CAT) dropped nearly 2% each to weigh heavy on the Dow in early trade. Both stocks had surged more than 3% in heavy trade Wednesday.
Guess (GES) pounded out an 11% gain despite mixed fourth quarter results. Other retailers fared not as well. Vince Holding (VNCE) skidded 10% lower, also on mixed fourth quarter results.

Arts and crafts chain Michaels (MIK) dipped 4%. Its fourth quarter sales and earnings met or topped consensus views. But management's Q1 earnings guidance missed analyst projections. The stock has been a ramrod, grabbing consecutive new highs. Thursday's loss left shares still extended and 65% above their June 2014 IPO price.
Three in five stocks on the IBD50 list opened lower, although losses were generally 1% or less.

The list's biggest gain was a 2% jump by Biogen (BIIB). The stock is inching into new highs this week as investors prepare for test results due Friday. Stocks reversed higher at the closing bell Monday, ending a four-session skid despite another rout in China's stock market and a further drop in oil prices.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today rose 10% on the Nasdaq and 6% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.
Energy, mining and biotech stocks lagged, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.
Aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) rose after hours following its Q4 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session down nearly 1%, declining for the eighth straight session.

Macy's (M) led the S&P 500, rising 8% in strong volume after investment advisory firm Starboard Value reportedly said Monday it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties. Other department store stocks also rallied, with Kohl's (KSS) rising 5% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.

On a sour note, IBD 50 stock Celgene (CELG) dropped nearly 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.
Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).

In Tuesday's column, we discussed the 10-week moving average as a gauge of a stock's resilience in a poor market. Support at the 10-week line hints at healthy demand by large investors.This begs the question: What should one do when a stock has tested this moving average numerous times?An examination of true market leaders shows that the 10-week line can act as a sturdy trampoline from which the stock bounces back to new highs, stretching the rally over months or years.However, there comes a time when such a pattern of action becomes unrepeatable.For that reason, IBD's rule is to add shares to an existing position, or initiate a position, in a highly rated stock only on the first or second successful test of the 10-week line after a breakout from a base. Later entry points may still make money, but the risk of losing money also rises, especially when the market grows sour.Consider Dollar General (DG), which has made a respectable run since it returned to the public markets following a multiyear restructuring.Two weeks ago, the stock bolted back above its 10-week line, snapping a three-week losing streak. Volume was unimpressive, though, below its 50-day average and less than the prior week.If an investor had bought shares, he or she would have to sell fast to pinch a small gain or break even.It was the wrong time to buy. The breakout from a lengthy double-bottom base took place in the week ended Sept. 2. Volume shot up to 15.6 million shares, the highest in three months. From there, the stock had found support at the 10-week line at least four times before the latest pullback.See the A1 story in Tuesday's IBD for details on Dollar General's April-quarter results.

Stocks were lower Tuesday morning, as an early push into mixed territory was short-lived. Hurt by chip and software stocks, the Nasdaq fell 0.6%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.2% each. Both briefly poked into positive territory. Turnover was running mixed in the stock market today.
Nasdaq trade was running higher compared with the same time Monday, but NYSE volume was tracking lower.

In stocks, Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) pared its loss to 3% after missing views late Monday. After Monday's close, the drugmaker posted Q3 earnings that rose 10% to $2.52. But it missed views by 4 cents. Sales climbed 11% to $340.9 million, also below views. Both its top and bottom lines decelerated for a third straight quarter. Shares gapped down and fell more than 8% at Tuesday's low.

Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) gapped down and dropped nearly 5% before trimming its loss.Microsemi (MSCC) announced in a press release that PMC-Sierra (PMCS) favors its buyout offer over Skyworks'. Both Skyworks and Microsemi announced plans to acquire PMC-Sierra last month.

On the upside, D.R. Horton (DHI) rallied 3% after beating views. Before the open, the homebuilder posted fiscal Q4 earnings of 64 cents a share, 2 cents above views. Sales came in at $3.09 billion vs. views of $3.04 billion. D.R. Horton closed on 10,576 homes during the quarter, up 23% from a year ago. The stock hit resistance at its 50-day moving average.

Appliance and electronics retailer Conn's cruised past earnings and sales estimates as furniture and mattress sales nearly doubled, sending shares spiking to a record high on Thursday Conn's (CONN) enjoyed strong gains across all its product categories — which also include consumer electronics, appliances and home office products — but its mattresses and furniture got most of the attention from…
Investors will look for signs of a turnaround at struggling Dollar Tree (DLTR) when the discount chain announces first-quarter earnings early Thursday.
Consensus is for a return to double-digit profit growth after EPS rose just 1% in Q4, with revenue slightly negative.

The 23 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters forecast that Dollar Tree will report 66 cent per-share profit, up 12% from the same quarter last year. Revenue is seen rising 7.5% to $2.01 billion from $1.87 billion.

Deep discount chains saw huge gains during and after the Great Recession. Although economic growth is benefiting many middle-tier shoppers, value shoppers are still constrained. Stubbornly high unemployment, weak wage growth and cutbacks in some government assistance programs such as food stamps are keeping a lid on spending.
As a result, the Retail-Discount/Variety group is ranked a dismal 182 on IBD's list of 197 industries.
Dollar Tree is trying to reinvent itself as a broader-line retailer, adding new goods and marketing to a wider market segment.
On its last conference call, CEO Bob Sasser said the company had earlier beefed up its checkout and impulse department, frozen and refrigerated products, stationery, candy and party supplies.

Mother Nature will play a role in the company's earnings. Severe weather impacted results in the final quarter of 2013. Sasser noted on the company's quarterly conference call in February that "out of the full 91 days in the quarter 33 days were negatively affected by winter storms that forced a large number of store closures."
Dollar Tree was down 1% in Monday morning trading on the stock market.

Rival Dollar General (DG), the largest deep discount chain, will report Q1 earnings on June 3. The company, which operates more than 11,000 stores, has annual revenue of about $17.5 billion and has beaten or matched analysts' EPS estimates for the last four quarters.
Consensus is for the company to record a 2.8% rise in EPS to 73 cents, on a 7.8% increase in revenue to $4.56 billion. Dollar General was up fractionally.
